It is one of the greatest diversification tools. It is a good environmental improvement. Yet we had Tory members saying they were going to oppose mechanisms for increasing the use of ethanol for our transportation fuels.
There certainly is a lot to be done. The estimates before us today cut R and D, which is not helpful to Canadian farmers. It is not helpful to rural Canadian agriculture.

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Kempling (Parliamentary Secretary to President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am honoured today to request on behalf of the President of the Treasury Board supply for the 1992-93 Main Estimates.
These Main Estimates reflect our continuing commitment to eliminate waste and inefficiency, control spending and contain the costs of government, the need for significant changes in the way government operates, and our commitment to deliver services to Canadians in the most efficient manner.
This year the Main Estimates total $160.5 billion. Through these estimates the government seeks Parliament's approval for $48 billion in new spending authority of which some $13 billion of interim supply was granted
Supply
earlier through Appropriation Act No. 1, 1992-93. The remaining $111.7 billion represent statutory payments that have already been granted previously with parliamentary approval.
Growth in the Main Estimates is the outcome of a number of decisions and factors affecting the budgets of all 135 programs delivered by the 116 departments, agencies and Crown corporations that appear in the estimates. This growth can be divided into two broad categories: adjustments to statutory items which amount to a net increase of $1.3 billion and changes to voted items which amount of $1.7 billion.
These Main Estimates fully reflect the government's continuing attempts to eliminate waste and inefficiency. This includes divesting itself of activities and organizations that no longer serve a vital public need in order to reduce costs and strike a proper balance between Canadians' demands for federal services and their ability as taxpayers to pay for those services.
In this regard much has been achieved over the past seven years. Program spending now represents only 16.7 per cent of Canada's Gross National Product as compared to 20 per cent in fiscal year 1984-85. During the same period the annual growth in program spending including Public Service salaries has averaged only 4 per cent as compared to an average inflation rate of 4.3 per cent.
In the 1991 budget a commitment was made to introduce legislation that would limit spending for the next five years. The Spending Control Act has been approved by this House and the spending plans outlined in the Main Estimates are well within the limits set out in that legislation.
These achievements clearly demonstrate the government's commitment to restraint and improved efficiency through the rigorous control of expenditures as well as the implementation of innovative management practices. They also reflect our commitment to good management and careful stewardship of the taxpayer's dollar.
The government's record since taking office in 1984 has been one of success. We are confident we are on the right track. Canadians have indicated that they want governments to spend less, to spend smarter and to be more efficient. To this end the government continues to scrutinize carefully resource requests by federal government agencies.

June 16, 1992
Supply
My colleague, the Minister of Finance in his latest budget, announced a series of initiatives intended to bring about immediate reductions in expenditures and contribute to lasting efficiencies in government programs and services.
First, a number of programs including grants and contributions is being reduced. Defence spending is being scaled back further. Expenditures on social housing will continue to grow but the rate of increase will be slower.
This government remains committed to the green plan and plans to spend $3 billion over the next six years. However some expenditures have been rescheduled for later years.
Second, the cost of government operations, that is the non-salary operating budgets, is being reduced a further 3 per cent. An additional $75 million in communications related expenditures is to be removed from the appropriations.
In addition to the expenditure reduction and reprofiling announced in the budget and in addition to the more than 20 Crown corporations that have been sold or dissolved since 1984, 46 separate organizations and advisory bodies will be wound up, privatized or consolidated with other organizations.
Cost recovery will also be extended to a number of additional areas with a view to moving the costs of providing specific services to the beneficiaries and away from the general taxpayer.
In today's difficult fiscal environment there are not enough tax dollars to meet all the financial demands of government programs. Cost recovery ensures that the best use is made of scarce resources. Through user fees and cost recovery the government is providing and improving services we might not otherwise be able to afford in order to ensure that the best use is made of scarce resources.
Ongoing restraints mean that the Public Service managers and organizations have to deal with increased demands for services on the one hand and ever decreasing resources on the other hand. The managers have to seek the balance in a creative, sensitive and constructive manner.
We also believe that an innovative, competent and dedicated Public Service is the key asset in supporting Canada's ability to compete. Dedicated and competent federal employees working across the country and in
missions abroad are working to serve Canadians in many areas such as health and safety, protection of consumer interests, support of industry regions, aboriginal people, science and technology, foreign aid, representing and protection of interests abroad, protection of persons and property, protection of taxpayers through effective and fair administration of the Income Thx Act and the Customs and Excise Acts, and delivery of social programs.
The government as the employer wishes to inform Canadians that its employees are doing many things to serve them better and to bring the government closer to them. To improve efficiency in the Public Service, innovation management practices remain a priority for this government.
Since taking office in 1984 we have introduced a wide range of initiatives to improve the management of operations. Many of the recent initiatives are the result of the major renewal exercise PS 2000 announced by the Prime Minister in 1989.
In support of this initiative a number of special operating agencies have been or are in the process of being established. Managers of special operating agencies have been given the ability and the flexibility to run their organizations more like a business with greater focus on results and service. This gives them greater freedom of action to serve Canadian taxpayers better and to respond quickly to changes in client needs.
Also, in the context of PS 2000, a system of operating budgets is currently being introduced which will be used to provide a far more realistic measure of the administrative costs of delivering programs and services. It too will give managers more flexibility to decide what is the most efficient distribution of their allocated resources.
Operating budgets will also allow managers to make the most economical use of scarce tax dollars in order to deliver services better and on a more timely basis. Operating budgets are expected to be in place government-wide by the beginning of 1993-94.
In conclusion, this government is committed to providing Canadians with the best service possible within the resources available. It is committed to a Public Service where employees focus first on the public they serve. To this end we must make it easier for our clients to deal with the government by providing simple and accessible services and we must make it easier for our managers to move in this direction.
June 16, 1992

We will do this by continuing to restructure government operations and provide training to our employees. To achieve these goals, federal government organizations will work together to make government services available at common points of delivery service. They will develop, where possible, standards of service based on consultation with clients. They provide more flexible and client oriented hours of service. They will reduce the number of forms to make them easier to complete. They will move to electronic procurement and invest in new technologies and training.
The message is clear. This government is serious about restraint. It is responding to the desire of Canadians that we reduce spending wherever possible. We are serious about reform and the need for new organizational approaches with which to operate the government in a manner that suits the needs of Canadians.
The measures that have been announced in the budget and reflected in these Main Estimates clearly indicate our commitment to sound fiscal management and to reduce the demands on the Canadian taxpayers.

Madam Speaker, I was interested in the speech of the hon. member for Burlington.
I know that he is very interested in science and technology, industrial diversification and the whole area of science and industrial design and so on. He talked about the government doing a slashing job on groups like the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada. I know the government is saving some $22 million with the wholesale destruction of those agencies.
In view of the member's interest in long term science policy and economic policy, I am wondering whether the government's move to slash all those agencies is out of concern or because of the politics of it, especially in western Canada and in other parts of the country with the Reform Party, and spending all of that money which I believe was $22 million on the 'feel good agenda' where we are trying to make people be happy and be satisfied and so on.
Supply
Does he feel that is a good trade-off. Should the Government of Canada be destroying long term agencies like the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada? Politicians by their very nature, with a mandate of only for four or five years, have to look at the short term. The Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada can take a broader view, perhaps a 10 year, 15 year or 20 year horizon as to what needs to be done in terms of retraining, education, science, specialities, direction, innovations or design that is good.
I am interested to know whether the hon. member feels that it is in the best interests of the country to slash agencies like the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada, to cut off that opportunity for a window on the wider world and, more important, on the horizon of those special areas of education, university and design and new perspectives on where we need to be going as a country for our industries.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the member poses an interesting question because the government has closed the two agencies to which he referred.
The question is: Is the information they supplied available from other sources? We are constantly being pushed by the academic world, in particular the universities, to help them in their research and development programs. The Minister of Industry, Science and Technology has introduced and put in operations centres of excellence in our universities across the country.
We find that we can get much of the information that we want, much of the research that we want through those universities. Thke the drug program that we introduced through the extension of the Patent Act under Bill C-22. Most of that research and many of the companies involved in it came to Canada because they felt that we have a good university program where they could tap into and get much of the research done for the new drugs and processes that they were putting forward in biotechnology and so forth to help our medical services across the country. It is the same with our industrial research. The member I know is aware of the disastrous programs that were introduced by previous governments in research and development that cost us billions of dollars in the final analysis, fraudulent schemes that

June 16, 1992
Supply
were put in place. I am not blaming the government for it. I am just blaming the way it was administered. There were fraudulent schemes that were put in place and exercised by many companies which came into the country, got research and development grants from the government and then disappeared out of the country again. There was no control over them. We have had a bad history in that regard.
I think what we have done is the right thing. The services that are available to us from our university communities are good. What we are doing with industry in research and development will continue to sustain our industry in the future. Certainly, in many of our industries we are leaders in the field and we will continue to be that way in the future.

Madam Speaker, as I have just returned from the earth summit in Rio, my questions for the parliamentary secretary will focus on the issues that flow out of that experience.
In Rio the government reaffirmed its commitment to give .7 per cent of GNP for foreign aid. Regrettably there was no timetable attached to that commitment. Over the last five years that commitment has in real terms actually decreased.
My first question is whether or not this is more than just nice words and no action, the usual strategy of this government, or whether there are some real dollar figures that are planned from Treasury Board.
My second question also concerns my experience in Rio. I was horrified to come back to Canada and hear that there was a proposal to spend $4.3 billion on military helicopters. When one considers the kind of priorities there are, there has to be a fundamental rethinking about what is valued and what environmental security means. I would ask the parliamentary secretary whether or not there is some concern in cabinet for what environmental security is and what is going to happen with that planned expenditure.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, if the Prime Minister of Canada made a commitment that he was going to propose to cabinet and to put through in government
spending a certain amount of money for foreign aid, it will be done. There is no doubt about that in my mind.
With regard to the helicopter acquisition, it has not come to cabinet yet. It is still being considered. The newspapers got hold of a story and they played it pretty well. Members, like the member who asked the question, have played on it.
The matter has not come before cabinet. It will be coming before cabinet. Much of that will be used for search and rescue. The condition of the 35-year-old helicopters that we have and the number of accidents they have had certainly indicate to me, at any rate, that these helicopters have to be replaced.
I would just say that the first time there is a need for search and rescue helicopters on either the west coast or the east coast and we do not have helicopters that are capable of going out and getting into that rescue operation, the hon. member will be on her feet, as will others, saying why are we not doing something about it.
We have equipment. Equipment wears out. These are 35 years old. There is talk of revitalizing them, putting new engines in them and so forth, but I do not know if that is such a good idea. We are going to have to replace those. Part of the replacement will come from the program that the government is going to be looking at in the very near future.

Madam Speaker, I have a very short question. Having seen the budget, there were many reductions. My colleague has talked about the different councils: the Economic Council, the Science Council, and the Law Reform Commission which in my opinion were worth-while. The hon. member said there were other places they could go for that expertise.
Has the parliamentary secretary seen any studies that might have recommended that the ministers' offices should be cut back?
I cannot see most of them being very cost-effective because they now have a chief of staff who is paid almost at the level of a deputy minister. It seems to me this cost is an ineffective use of Parliament.
June 16, 1992

I am wondering if the parliamentary secretary would like to comment on that because I think there are an excessive number of ministries. Possibly some of them could be cut out altogether or doubled up.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, ministerial staff is the prerogative of the minister.
I can recall when I was in opposition one of the members of her party who sits in the front row had an exempt staff of over 125 people. I have never seen a parallel of that in our government. People on ministerial staff can be shuffled into various areas.
Name it.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
I am not going to name it. The hon. member knows better than to ask that question.
The shuffling of staff from one side to the other goes on quite a little bit. If the ministers need the staff to carry out the programs they are engaged in then they should have the staff to do so.

Madam Speaker, there is a motion before this House that asks us to concur in the Main Estimates of the spending of the Government of Canada through to the end of the year, March 31, 1993.
As we look at these estimates we can talk about all that things that are happening and are not happening in the country. We can talk about financial matters and those other matters that concern the country very deeply.
There are certainly many problems that face this country today that are of a very serious nature. However, that is no reason for anyone in the House or any Canadian to go around being deeply concerned about how we are going to handle it, whether we are going to handle it, and what is going to happen to the future of our country.
If we have the determination and the insight, if we have learned something from past history in this country and from the past leaders of this country, from the people in the past who put this nation together over the years, then we will look at the past to get an answer to the present. If we have any vision in this country, any vision in ourselves, we will be able to look to the future and put it together.
I do not fear that Canadians today cannot meet the challenges that are facing us right now. However it is
Supply
going to take leadership in this country and it is going to take serious dedication on the part of every member of Parliament, every senator, and every Canadian from coast to coast to coast in this country.
I want to go on the premise of our forefathers, of the sound foundation that has been built in this country over the years by people who had faith in themselves, faith in their country, faith in their fellow human beings, their comrades, and faith in God.
God has given us a great gift. It is called Canada. How we as generations of Canadians manage this Canada of ours is our gift to God, and I suggest that we not let our Maker down.
One thing that is bothering me greatly, as we have this last day for the study of the estimates for this fiscal year, is that the federal government is unloading its burdens on to other levels of government in this country, namely the provinces, the municipalities and right through to the very doorsteps of every individual taxpaying Canadian.
The estimates for this fiscal year are $160.5 billion. A new financial structure is going to be needed in this country and it is going to be needed now because the financial structure is all out of whack as a result of the niggling process of trying to pass the buck to somebody else.
With all my heart and every inch of my sincerity I maintain that the buck stops right here in the House of Commons of Canada. This is where the leadership has got to come from if we are going to manage this nation well.
Yes, we have a farm crisis in this country. It has been very well outlined by the hon. member for Algoma, who has an in-depth knowledge of the farm community and its difficulties in this country.
Supply management programs must be protected at all costs and they can only be protected if each and every one of us is determined to protect the farm community in this country. I grew up on a farm in this country. I have done all the chores that anyone could think of. I milked my two cows before I walked six and a half miles to high school because there were no school buses. I came home after school, got on the tractor, went out to the fields, drove the team of horses, milked the cows and tried to do my homework in the interim. It never hurt me and I recommend it to everybody.

June 16, 1992
Supply
There is nothing wrong with this nation today that a good dose of national spirit, personal determination, and the ability of every one of us to pull our weight would not fix. This country needs dedication. We have this great nation, this great gift that God has given us, called Canada. Let us manage it by working for it and not be afraid and back away from things in case we are going to fail.
We can never be afraid of failure because that is the first step to failure.
We must protect our farm system today because this country has been blessed with some of the greatest health standards in food anywhere in the world. I congratulate our Department of Agriculture and its officials for that, and the leaders of the past who put these programs together. Our health standards are excellent.
We need security of food in this country because any nation that cannot feed itself is in danger. That is a terrible failure. Over the beautiful farm lands and open fields of this country waves that great Canadian flag day in and day out, as it does over the small villages, towns and cities of this country. Let us get up in the morning and say how grateful we are to be Canadians. Let us go out and deliver the message to our neighbours and friends and inspire them to go on and build Canada, this Canada that cares greatly for her own people.
We have health care in this country that is unparalleled. If there is anything that we must do, if we think anything about our friends and neighbours at all, it must be to ensure that this is retained in the social structure of this country. I am sure every Canadian wants to see that done, but it requires determination and good management.
In my years in this House I have made some tremendous friends on both sides of this Chamber, and I have some good friends on both sides of this Chamber today. I appeal to everybody, at this moment and as they get up each morning, to say that we, the citizens of Canada, have the greatest opportunity to do things not only for ourselves in this country and not only to feel for those people who are unemployed and those people who do not have good health but we must have a heart and we must have a heart for them. National Revenue must
have a heart for those people who are suffering and cannot pay their taxes because they had to feed their kids first. They have a wife and family to support.
I hope that the Minister of National Revenue will see it in his heart to back off on some of the sad cases that are coming forward. I have a number of them myself and my heart goes out to them. Our greatest resource is our people. Let us help them through this difficult time.
Our national resources are another point in question. Softwood lumber had a tremendous downturn when the Minister for International Trade signed that 15 per cent tax against softwood lumber going into the United States. We know it was not part of the free trade agreement but we also know that it was signed just before the free trade agreement was signed and the softwood lumber people in this area, and in my own Ottawa Valley which has been hurt terribly, were the sacrificial lambs of this government signing a free trade agreement with the United States. Let there be no question about that. Our lumber and natural resources have suffered ever since.
Even though it has been taken off, after many suffered as a result of it, the United States is now coming back and trying to nail us with it anyway. We will be interested to see what the report is.
The hon. member from Superior and-how could I forget? As a student I stood out on the highway in Cochrane hitch-hiking all night to get to Long Lac where I had a summer job. The member for Cochrane-Superior has brought this issue out extremely well.
Let us not say that it just happened on its own. This government has always said that we must compete. I could not agree more with it, and I do not think any member in this House could! agree more. We must compete with the world if we are going to live but we are not going to compete in this world if we have a lack of commitment on the part of the government for research and development in this nation. Yes, we must talk about competing but the research and development programs of this country, or of any other country, are the engine that drives the economy. That is what answers the competition.
If it is the determination, the desire and the will of the government not to do R and D in the way that it should be done to benefit all Canadians then it is failing in its
June 16, 1992

effort to compete at the same time as it is saying we must compete.
Emergency Preparedness Canada's training centre in Arnprior is an issue I want to raise at this time. For months on end the people in that community and Canadians from both territories and all 10 provinces of Canada, 3,000 people a year, come to that Emergency Preparedness Canada training centre in Arnprior to take training courses to handle disasters in their communities across this nation. There were great rumours it was going to be moved out of that centre. We had a large rally recently. I have been asking questions and raising the matter in the House. Finally the other day the Minister of Supply and Services, who is the regional minister for eastern Ontario, gave a commitment in writing to the Mayor of Arnprior this facility would stay in Arnprior and in the Ottawa Valley, and I thank him for that. I am not vindictive about these things.
I am a fighter for things for the Ottawa Valley and I am a fighter for things for Canada. When a person makes a commitment, then I thank him for it and I want that commitment kept. I want it kept for the county of Renfrew because it was very much involved in this.
Canada has had problems over the years. Today we have many problems but these are not unnatural. Every nation has its problems. As I said in the beginning, it depends on the will and determination of Canadians generally to face up to these problems of today. That is going to tell the rest of this country whether or not we have the conviction and faith within ourselves that our ancestors had to solve these problems and carry on with this great nation called Canada.
This is Canada. I am a Canadian nationalist. I have been a Canadian nationalist from the word go. I am not a Scot, I am not Irish and I am not English. I am Canadian and I will be one until the day I die. I almost got thrown out of a history class in high school because I was fighting for our Canadian flag. I am proud of that day and I have had some great discussions with that teacher since.
What is the sense of discussing all these other great issues today and worrying about them if, first of all, we do not have a united Canada? The difficulties over Canadian history have been great. One of the greatest things that has ever been done, one of the greatest
Supply
visions of this country was building the first railroad across this nation.
To put things in perspective, let us go back to 1840 in Canadian history. Lord Stanley, who was the British Colonial Secretary from England at the time, said and I quote: "I have to express the hope that the formation of the Government of Canada may have the effect of extinguishing party and national animosities and of directing the minds of men in Canada"-You know it is not our generation now, because we would say "men and women in Canada"-"of whatever origin to the advancement of the prosperity of their native or adopted country". That was in 1840 and there were problems. We are still trying to face up to those problems today.
Then there is a quote from Stephen Leacock in 1926 regarding the contribution of those two great Canadians who worked prior to Confederation, Robert Baldwin and Louis Lafontaine. Stephen Leacock had this to say:
From now on a new path of national development is indicated in the alliance and co-operation of the two races, English and French, each contributing its distinctive share to the political life of the country, and each finding in the other a healthful stimulus and support. This is the principle, entirely contrary to the doctrines of the older school, first introduced by the alliance of Baldwin and Lafontaine, which has since governed the destinies of Canada. On the validity of this principle, the future of the country has been staked.
It is a great and well-earned tribute to Baldwin and Lafontaine because they did a lot prior to 1867 in the 1840s, 1850s and 1860s to make this a great nation. George-Etienne Cartier had this to say in 1855:
In the alliance which we have made between Upper and Lower Canada-we have not abandoned any of our positions.
Those are the words of great statesmen, so let us practise a little bit of that today. They had their nationhood idea and were trying to bring the races and various groups in Canada together. It is a great credit to the Fathers of Confederation after conferences in Quebec City and Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, that in 1867 a nation consisting of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Ontario and Quebec and the rest of the territories of Canada was brought together.
B.C. entered in 1871 on the promise a railroad would be built across the country. We know all the little scandals and the problems of bringing that railway to pass, but in 1885 it happened and B.C. remained in Canada.

Supply
We also remember the American Civil War between 1860 and 1864 ended up with a victory for the north. The Americans had a tremendous army at their command at that time. They had a great idea they were going to become the continentalists in North America. Some wanted to go right through to the North Pole and claim all of what is Canada today.
But what happened? The Fathers of Confederation saw this happening. They had the minds of statesmen and used them. That is why they brought Canada together in 1867, so we could protect ourselves from the pushing and aggressive interests from south of the border we see today.
Continentalism was what the Americans called it then. What is it today with free trade and the lumber issue I mentioned? They are still trying to come on to Canada and push us right to the wall. We, as Canadians, have to stick together today just as we stuck together in 1867. There must be unity within this nation. That line of steel started to be built across the country and Manitoba, a great province of Canada, entered Confederation in 1870. In 1873 that beautiful island, Prince Edward Island, joined Confederation. Saskatchewan and Alberta came in 1905, carved out of the territories of western Canada. Newfoundland came in 1949, and then we had Canada and the two territories.
This was leadership, Madam Speaker.
I want to end on this great note, because I want to appeal to every Canadian in every province of Canada. I want to appeal to those who are handling our constitutional debate today.
Let us remember over in Europe, tens of thousands of young Canadians are resting row on row in those cemeteries. They went over there to defend Canada, to defend freedom and to defend other free nations of the world. There were 619,636 Canadians who participated in World War I and 66,655 died. They were Canadians and young people. If you look at those grave markers you will see how young-18, 19, 20, 23, 24 years of age. They were young people who never had an opportunity to participate in the history of their nation, but they saved this nation for us, and are an inspiration to us.
They came from all over Canada. In World War II more than one million Canadians went to war to save
freedom once again. We lost 45,000 Canadians in World War II. They too are sleeping far away from their homeland, but they fought for freedom. They fought for us so we could have this great nation and participate in a free world.
Then we joined the United Nations in the Korean war in 1950, 1951, 1952 and 1953.
Five hundred and sixteen Canadians are resting in Korea as a result of having fought under the UN flag in those years. We have done a great job peacekeeping around the world.
Just remember, we do not have Remembrance Day in this nation only on November 11 each year. Today is remembrance day. Remember all those Canadians who sacrificed their lives to save Canada's freedom and fight for the free world. Let us as Canadians determine today we have the destiny within ourselves to co-operate with one another, to tone down our demands and try to get along together as good neighbours. Let us build this great nation God has given us.
If we do not, we have failed. I do not want a single member sitting in this House today to ever leave Parliament and have any of our children or our grandchildren in the future say: "My father or mother or grandmother was a member of Parliament when this country failed itself"
I want to thank hon. members from all over this House for listening very intently. I have a great feel for members on both sides of this House. I think that is the kind of spirit we have to put into building the Canadian Constitution and uniting this nation. I call for my friends from Quebec, from every province of Canada and the territories, our aboriginal peoples and everyone, to make Canada great. Let us get on with our great nation, help our fellow man and help bring peace on an ongoing basis to the world.

Madam Speaker, I just want to compliment the member for his excellent remarks and the spirit in which he made them in this House on a non-partisan basis.
I think they are the kind of remarks we do not hear enough of in this House. I think the remarks were well placed today.
June 16, 1992

Madam Speaker, I too want to share the thoughts of my former colleague from Mississauga with the member for Renfrew-Nipissing-Pembroke, who came to this House in 1965 as I did.
There was a certain celebration here last night for the class of 1968, but they are sort of young members here. Some of us are from the class of 1965 and are getting a little longer in the tooth.
I listened on television and came here to hear the end of his speech because of my personal respect for the hon. member and his generally objective view on most things, although most of us share party labels.
I obviously agree with him totally in terms of what he says about the state of the country and the fact we, as members, have a very special duty to help resolve those constitutional problems. I know how he feels sentimentally, but I would just like to ask him how he feels in terms of Parliament. We have seen all the negotiations and everything has been ticking away outside of this forum.
We have a referendum bill that already puts a three-day time limit on a referendum question if we get to that point. Does he not feel, as an experienced member, this House has to become seized of this in a real way in a very short period of time, if the negotiators in those conference halls outside of Parliament are not able to come up with some type of offer to present to Quebec?
This is the House of Commons for the country. What really bothers me about the process, although it is much better than the Meech Lake process, is the time clock is ticking. We might not be able to come up with a reasonable situation to offer to Quebec. Is it his personal opinion, as a parliamentarian with long experience, that if we can come up with the offer, that in effect, as some people have written, especially in the Quebec press, let us have the referendum in Quebec, whatever the question may be and just see how that province decides on a very precise question its relationship with Canada.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
If I may, it is one o'clock p.m. The hon. member would have the floor after Question Period. I think it would not be fair for him to answer such a question in 20 seconds.
It being one o'clock, I do now leave the chair until two o'clock p.m.
The House took recess at 1 p.m.

AFTER RECESS

The House resumed at 2 p.m.

Mr. Speaker, currently the average Canadian taxpayer has absolutely no sympathy for the administrative problems of Canada's revenue department. The cross-border shopping craze is a rebellion against over-taxation, nothing more and nothing less.
The Minister of National Revenue's answer to overtaxation would be to impose some more taxes by this thing he calls harmonization of the PST and GST.
When is the minister going to quit putting measures in place at border crossings which do nothing more than cause Canadian shoppers to show more ingenuity when they are returning from their shopping sprees in the U.S.?
When is the minister going to do something positive about cross-border shopping? For example, let him lower the federal excise tax on gasoline, which is the main culprit that forces Canadians to shop in the U.S. in the first place.

Mr. Speaker, the Obstetrician and Gynaecologist Society of Canada wants the federal government to legalize the pill RU-486 for abortion purposes in Canada.
RU-486 pathologically affects the lining of the pregnant women's womb, causing the baby to undergo slow and agonizing starvation, followed by death and expulsion from the body. The drug has been known to cause fatal internal bleeding in some women.
The society is reported to have stated that: "The problem of legalizing the use of RU-486 is not with the government, but with the company itself, for fear of reaction from the pro-life people".

It is my opinion that the Obstetrician and Gynaecologist Society of Canada now considers itself the chief advocate and lobby group for Rousell Canada, the drug manufacturer, pushing for the legalization of RU-486.
I would expect that the government will remain firm and steadfast and not be swayed in any way in this decision to refuse the use of this drug for abortion use in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to read a message from several hundred members of the Yamaska Valley Chapter of the Canadian Club, in my riding, to their anglophone fellow citizens in the other provinces.

We of the Canadian Club of the Yamaska Valley, in the Eastern Townships of Quebec, wish to tell you of the enrichment we feel in our lives because we have an opportunity to partake in two cultures. We consider this diversity a bonus. This province is not unique, just different. Most provinces have languages and customs which they treasure and want to keep. Quebec feels the need to preserve what it has and we accept this. We do think that a compromise can, and will be achieved, so that Canada will remain a united country.
A positive attitude recognizing that we are a privileged people is essential. These privileges were given to us as Canadians to enjoy and to share. Let us not lose sight of this.

I hope this message will be heard and understood across the country.

Mr. Speaker, a report prepared for a number of environmental groups in New Brunswick has called attention to the fact that there may be a serious situation developing at the Point Lepreau reactor in New Brunswick where aging high pressure steam pipes located over the control room might pose a potential hazard.
Apparently AECB has issued a warning to New Brunswick Power and this warning has so far been ignored. Also, concern has been registered over the fact that Point Lepreau or New Brunswick Power has not filed an emergency plan like they were asked to do by AECB after the Chernobyl disaster. In fact, all nuclear reactors were asked to file such plans.
I would ask the government in my statement today to get in touch with the AECB and to ask it to get tough with New Brunswick Power to make sure we do not have any kind of nuclear accident in that province.
Now is the time to do something about these things, not after the fact. This report ought not to be discredited as it was earlier in the House today simply because the person who prepared it had something to do with Greenpeace. It is groups like Greenpeace and others who have warned us before the fact about other possible hazards.
It is time we listened now rather than wait until something happens.

Mr. Speaker, Bill C-21 removed the government's obligation to contribute to the unemployment insurance fund.
The fund is made up of employee-employer contributions and not government money. It is to be administered by the LFDB and it requested that the spending for developmental use be increased from $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion.
In a feeble effort to make it look as if the government is actually doing something positive for the unemployed, the Minister of Finance said: "We increased worker training and adjustment funds under the unemployment insurance program".
What he failed to mention was that this is not government money but it is the unemployment insurance contributions from employers and employees that he is using.
For example, community development projects are aimed at helping remote areas adjust to the changing market needs. This includes promoting alternative markets to whatever may have once fueled the local economy and I repeat, the local economy.
June 16, 1992

The local economy of P.E.I., in particular Hillsborough, has a record high unemployment rate which is having a tremendous impact on my constituents' lives, families, and well-being.
I ask the minister not to shuffle money around at the expense of the unemployed in Canada. If he is going to shuffle money around, shuffle it in the right places to help these unfortunate Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, today I would like to draw the attention of the House to the pride and determination shown by a company in my riding, United Parcel Service Canada Limited. UPS, which provides a parcel delivery service over land across Canada, in addition to having its own air mail delivery service which also operates throughout the country, has acquired a reputation for providing quality service.
The company does 48 inspections on each aircraft before every daily departure. The company has also become a significant player in the trucking industry. UPS tries to improve its employees' knowledge of safe driving practices, and it is one of the leading companies in North America in providing safety training for its employees.
I applaud the determination of UPS to provide an outstanding mail delivery service, which confirms the feelings of pride reflected by the UPS team.

Mr. Speaker, the government's approach to our youth, our students, is absolutely morally scandalous. The government has a brutal consistency. It attacks those who are most vulnerable, including young people between the ages of 15 to 24.
The unemployment rate, according to Statistics Canada, for Newfoundland youth was 34 per cent last year this time and it is now 36 per cent.
Combined with full-time students, the over-all rate for these groups, youth and students, is 43 per cent according to the latest statistics.
What has the government done? It has gutted transfer payments for post-secondary education. It has cut back on Challenge funding for summer employment by nearly $1 million in Newfoundland alone. It has tampered with Canada's student loans.
Our most vulnerable and precious resource is being wilfully pillaged by this government.
I ask this government now to retrace its steps, to amend its ways and to do something for that important group of people who are our future, while there is time left to do so.

Mr. Speaker, with the break-up of Yugoslavia and the recognition of new nations such as Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia-Hercegovi-na, some are seeking the recognition of another new state which is referred to as Macedonia.
Whereas the Government of Canada supports the principles of self-determination and independence, we must not forget the history of this region. Archeologists and experts in ancient history will affirm that Macedonia is inherently woven into the fabric of Hellenic civilization.
On the other hand, the People's Socialist Republic of Macedonia is a post-World War II creation of Tito's Yugoslavia and is a falsification and expropriation of the concept of Macedonia. It is a deliberate and malicious attack on Hellenic history and culture.
I urge the Government of Canada not to recognize the so-called state of Macedonia. Another name is fine, but not the name of Macedonia. I further recommend the government work with the United Nations and the European Community to ensure that the Government of Skopje gives up its false and provocative claims to Greek culture, history and territory.

June 16, 1992

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, members of the Canadian Union of Postal Workers have been without a contract since the summer of 1989. Despite the appointment of a conciliation officer in October 1989, of a conciliation board in October 1990, and a mediator in September 1991, the union is still without a contract.
Canada Post negotiators have attempted to deny that agreements were reached on many major issues during and following the mediation phase. For example, on the issue of wages, the government says it was not able to reach an agreement. In fact, both parties did agree on that issue.
I call upon the government to stop procrastinating and solve this matter forthwith.

Mr. Speaker, over the last few weeks there was concern raised in this House that Canada's big banks would nail consumers for higher service charges to cover their mistake loans to the floundering real estate giant, Olympia & York.
In response, the Minister of Finance made it clear he would not tolerate the banks trying to recover their loan losses from small businesses or average Canadians. He contacted the Canadian Bankers' Association and spelled out his concerns. He also told this House he was standing squarely on the side of bank clients.
The man the press is now calling "Mad Maz, the consumers' friend", has got results. Last week several banks announced they are freezing their service fees for a period of time as a visible gesture that the O&Y mistake will not end up costing us all more money.
I want to congratulate the banks for their gutsy response to this public concern and of course we are all in debt to Mad Maz, the caped crusader of Canadian consumerism.

Mr. Speaker, at this first opportunity to speak in the House since returning from the earth summit in Rio, I want to express my deep admiration and thanks to the Canadian negotiating team for their outstanding work on our behalf.
These women and men have given of themselves tirelessly over the past two years and in the final days and nights of negotiation in Rio worked around the clock. These 16 people are public servants in the truest sense.
Thank you John Bell, Vic Buxton, George Greene, Michael Small, Bob Applebaum, Serge April, Jerry Beausoliel, Alexandra Bezeredi, Barbara Brown, Louise Cote, Adrian DeHoog, David Drake, Fern Hurtubise, Jag Maini, John Sloan and Roger Street. You are among the heroes of the earth summit. I hope you can rest up, see your families and recharge your batteries for the crucial follow-up work.
Merci beaucoup.

Mr. Speaker, the cattlemen and women of this country and indeed of North America are being attacked by environmentalists and animal rights groups.
Cows and bulls have existed on this planet since Adam and Eve and in fact the Lord asked Noah to preserve all species because of a big cloudburst a few years ago.
Now these brain-warped animal rights groups and environmentalists, who all gorge themselves on big Macs, blame beef for causing heart attacks. They blame the cow with its forward and backward belches, you know what I mean Mr. Speaker, for causing a hole in the ozone.
Cattlemen are now blamed for feeding grain, grass and silage to these cows while Third World children starve. Cows provide milk, butter, cheese, fat, meat, leather, protein, calcium, fertilizer, recycled, and hundreds of thousands of jobs. Cows are perfect examples of sustainable development. Take away the moo, in fact the oink or the baa, and the entire world starves.
June 16, 1992

Mr. Speaker, this morning the Minister of Employment and Immigration tabled a bill with numerous and complex amendments to the Immigration Act.
In this bill he provided for extensive management and enforcement measures but virtually ignored humanitarian considerations. Most serious, he did not take any steps to provide for an appeal on the merits for refugees whose applications are rejected.
The Refugee Board is not perfect and without a fair appeal process the system is seriously flawed. As an alternative, why did the minister not clarify and provide objective criteria for the use of section 114, the admission of refugees on humanitarian and compassionate grounds? This useful provision has been virtually shut down by this minister as a means of appealing deserving cases. During the past year only four out of 889 of these applications were accepted in Quebec and only 16 out of 2,288 in Ontario.
I ask the minister of immigration to put more balance in his bill and provide for a fair appeal process.

Mr. Speaker, in Vancouver last week, the Quebec Federation of Labour decided to split from the Canadian Labour Congress.
This decision came as a result of the CLC's refusal to recognize the QFL's specific role in representing the workers of Quebec.
This is just one more instance that proves Quebecers must have their own institutions to become complete masters of their own destiny and become full participants in international organizations.
The QFL realizes that after many attempts, by both sides I agree, there is a total lack of compatibility between Canadian organizations and Quebec organizations. This decision will make it possible eventually to
Oral Questions
create a single labour congress in Quebec and will encourage Quebecers to take similar action in all areas.

Mr. Speaker, the International Heart Health Conference chaired by Canadian-born Dr. John Farqhuhar was held in Victoria, British Columbia, on May 24 to 28, gathering over 700 delegates.
The Conference Advisory Board issued a declaration that clearly states that our nation has the capacity to drastically reduce the incidence of heart disease and stroke.
Canadians will be able to achieve this if we reinforce our commitment to maintaining the cornerstones of good heart health, good dietary habits, tobacco-free lifestyles, regular physical activity, and a supportive psycho-social environment.
I am sure all hon. members will join me in congratulating the Conference Advisory Board, including Senator Dr. Wilbert Keon, representing the Canadian Cardiovascular Society on the board, for its efforts in improving heart health world-wide.

['Mr. Speaker, during Question Period, in answering a question by the hon. member for Yukon, I used the words "intelligent question".\nThis did not translate what I actually meant. I do not want to impute that the hon. member is not an intelligent person. I should have used the word "pertinent". That is what I meant. If I caused any heartache, or whatever, to the hon. member I wish to apologize.']

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Prime Minister. Yesterday the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tburism said in this House he could not make a premature disclosure as to the contents of the deal between Canada, the United States, and Mexico, and we will find out what is in the deal only after it is signed.
I want to ask the Prime Minister: Is it the policy of the government that the minister was representing when he said that the Canadian people and the House of Commons will not hear anything about the deal until it is signed?

June 16, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know whether the hon. Leader of the Opposition appreciates it but he is mis-stating and distorting the facts.
We have been quite open in presenting to this House various positions we have been taking in the North American free trade negotiations. There have been extensive meetings with his caucus representatives and the chief negotiators. We have also had extensive meetings with the various industry sector groups which are advising us on the negotiations.
As my hon. friend the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism has said, the final details cannot be known until the final negotiations are completed. We have been very open in a variety of ways of making sure that people do understand the clear objectives we have and some of the specific negotiating issues we are dealing with.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the minister or the Prime Minister. I would like to ask them what they are proposing at this time when they say the people are being consulted. We are talking to some premiers who are complaining bitterly because they have not heard anything from the government, let alone the people. Provincial governments have not heard anything from the government.
If this government thinks we will be faced with a fait accompli the government has another thought coming because we will not tolerate that.
If the government does not want to take this House into its confidence about this deal, will the government at least make the commitment that when it has signed this deal between Canada, the U.S. and Mexico, that it will authorize a committee of this House to have public hearings before this House is confronted with a vote. The Canadian people are entitled at least to be heard before we vote in this House.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me direct my response to the two things that the hon. member has raised.
First of all, as far as the provinces are concerned, we have had something like 35 meetings with the provinces
over the last year on the issues. My hon. friend is, I am sure, referring to statements that were made by some premiers who were not aware. They had not been briefed or they chose not to acknowledge that they had been briefed on the results of these meetings. I have seen members of the provincial governments express their deep appreciation for the way that we have consulted with them and taken into account their views.
On the question of the activities of this House prior to the signing of an agreement, there will be every opportunity for a committee of this House to take the initialled agreement, have hearings on that initialled agreement, take the advice of various interested parties, parties that have been involved in the negotiation through the sectoral advisory process, and in that way the views of Canadians will be heard before the deal would be signed.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, promises of the kind the minister just made tend to be received with some scepticism by Canadians, because during the last election campaign, the Prime Minister and the government made a very firm commitment to introducing adjustment programs for Canadian workers and companies. Three and half years later, none of these programs has been implemented. My question is directed to the minister or the Prime Minister. Before making any commitments under the new agreement with the United States and Mexico, does the government intend to introduce adjustment programs for Canadian workers, and will it do so immediately, and not by way of an election promise but by introducing legislation in this House, before the government is defeated by Canadian voters?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Tirade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I regret that I have to say this a second time, but my hon. friend is totally mis-stating what we have done as a government.
My hon. friend refers to what we said we would do at the time of the free trade agreement with the United States. We appointed a commission headed by Jean de Grandpre. It had representatives from the business community and the labour community. This committee made recommendations to the Government of Canada to increase the amount of training. This has been done.

Oral Questions
My colleague has said a number of times that we have increased training from $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion. We have launched the Canadian Labour Force Development Board with representatives from labour and business to advise the government on the use of these training funds.
It was the policy of his party to delay the legislation that was going to implement the recommendations of the de Grandpre committee. If he is worried about-
Order, please.

Yesterday, in asking questions about what was in the agreement and what was not in it with reference to subsidies, the Minister of State for Small Businesses replied: "The government will announce what is in the agreement when it is signed".
Let me ask the Minister of International Trade, who says that is not the government's position, two questions:
In defending the existing free trade agreement with the United States, the government invariably points to the dispute settlement mechanism. Yet that mechanism, the centrepiece of the free trade agreement, is on the table in the current trilateral negotiations as the North American Free Trade Agreement supersedes the FTA.
Are United States negotiators seeking to water down the dispute settlement mechanism? Is that a price Canada will have to pay for a North American free trade agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
No, Mr. Speaker, it will not be the price that Canada has to pay, to use my hon. friend's words.
I also use the words that he used before, right after the last election when he said "every sparrow that falls will be blamed on the free trade agreement". Here is another sparrow that he is throwing out into the air right now. My hon. friend should know that in this agreement, as in any trade negotiation, nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.
I have responded to his questions. The chief negotiator has responded to his questions in the briefings that he is
receiving. The openness that this government has demonstrated to the opposition parties and others in discussing what the negotiations are designed to achieve is totally different from anything that his government or previous Liberal governments have ever done in terms of letting Canadians know about what they are planning to negotiate or not negotiate in any trade negotiations.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that the minister finds my ornithological metaphors so pleasing, but they do not in fact answer the question that I am asking, nor has he answered the question that I just put to him: Is the dispute settlement being renegotiated or not? However, the minister declines to answer that so let me move on to another question.
A major omission in the existing Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement is the absence of provisions regarding financial services on the one hand and government procurement on the other. Indeed, the government justified its entiy into the current North American free trade negotiations to correct those and other anomalies in the free trade agreement.
Since the minister claims that he is seeking to improve the free trade agreement in the current North American negotiations, will there be provisions in the North American free trade agreement regarding financial services and regarding government procurement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Tkade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the answer to that question is yes and yes.
Let me just respond to the question that my hon. friend raised about the dispute settlement mechanism. We have made it very clear right from the start of these negotiations that things that were negotiated in the free trade agreement with the United States will not be renegotiated in the NAFTA agreement unless they can be improved upon. That certainly applies to the dispute settlement mechanism which was a centrepiece of our acceptance of the free trade agreement with the United States and has been a centrepiece in the success of the free trade agreement since that time.

June 16, 1992
Oral Questions
With regard to financial services and procurement, these matters are both under negotiation. We have made it clear in both cases what our objectives are. In the case of procurement, if we are able to get a Uruguay round success at the same time, the procurement package will be a considerably larger one and a very attractive one as far as Canadian industry is concerned.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade.
The minister has said that Canadians will not know what is in the deal until it is signed. We even do not know the official statistics on this government's assessment and Canadians' assessment of the Canadian-U.S. trade deal and yet the government is taking us blindly into a trade deal when all we do know is that we have lost almost a half a million jobs because of the Canada-U.S. trade deal.
The minister has said that he is going to go out to Canadian business and ask it to help sell the deal. I remind the minister that just before the Canada-U.S. trade deal was signed the same multinational corporations in their campaign said: "Okay, what's in it for me: More jobs, better jobs, more wealth to improve government services such as day care and direct personal benefits. You will find that the average food bill for a family of four will go down $100 a year".
Is that the kind of promises that the minister wants business to go out and sell? Canadians know better. Why does the minister not do the right thing and, rather than trying to sell a bad deal, pull out of these negotiations and give Canadians a real birthday present.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I guess my hon. friend is still the spokesperson for the Canadian Labour Congress, but I think she has got her figure wrong. Rather than the 500,000 jobs that she stated were lost, the Canadian Labour Congress figures it is 1.4 million. She should get her figures right. Both of these figures are wildly out of perspective.
As I have said on many occasions if we have a record level of exports to the United States, if exports are up something like 5 per cent or 6 per cent since the free trade agreement came into force, how is it that is causing
us lost jobs in Canada? It is the reverse. The free trade agreement with the United States is helping this economy through a difficult period. The $5 billion or $6 billion increase in exports translates into something like 75,000 or 85,000 incremental jobs since 1988 as a result of the free trade agreement.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question. I would suggest that the minister talk to those thousands and indeed millions of Canadians who are out of work. We have 1.75 million Canadians out of work. Then he will get the straight goods. Then he will know what the economic policies and trade policies of this government have done to Canadians.
I want to say it has been clear from the beginning of the negotiations of the Canada-U.S. trade deal and now the NAFTA deal that there are parallel talks going on in other areas. This government has repeatedly said that these trade deals do not affect social policies.
We saw the generic drug bill that was passed before the Canada-U.S. trade deal. Now the immigration bill which was introduced clearly indicates that there is a move toward harmonization of immigration policies with the United States.
I want to ask the minister responsible whether it is the intention of this government to continue drawing Canada into the United States by harmonizing Canada's immigration policy with that of the United States?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member would be well advised, instead of standing up and making such a statement, to read the projected bill, try to inform herself and try not to mistake the position of the government, and then maybe we can answer an intelligent question.

Mr. Speaker, all we would like is an intelligent answer.
I have a supplementary question for the minister. Last September, as the minister knows, senior officials of the Canadian government met with senior officials of the Mexican and U.S. governments to discuss harmonization of refugee and immigration policy.
June 16, 1992

I want to say to the minister that Canada has had a long and proud history of admitting immigrants and refugees to this country on the basis of need, and not on the basis of wealth. I want to ask the minister whether it this government's intention to change those principles simply to cater to the needs of the United States, or whether there is going to be some sovereignty in Canada in developing our own immigration and refugee policies?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
No, Mr. Speaker. This is about furthering the view of the United Nations that the problem of genuine refugees is an international problem.
By the way, that is probably why today the United Nations high commission representative in Canada issued a communique endorsing fully the provisions of this bill fine-tuning our refugee determination process.
These people seem to look at the refugee determination system as an immigration problem. This is not an immigration problem. This is an undertaking by Canada to the world as a signatory of the UN Geneva convention to give protection to those people who need it. We are trying to exert Canada's influence throughout the world in order to give real protection to those persons who really need protection.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister for International Trade.
On May 11 the minister stated in this House: "If the United States does not allow the softwood issue to go to the dispute settlement mechanism panel then it will be a very serious thing".
Yesterday the U.S. Coalition for Fair Lumber Imports stated that the issue does not come under the free trade agreement and therefore is not subject to chapter 19 of the agreement.
What is the government's plan to avoid the issue being settled solely by American law?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, our plan is quite simply to file a joint request by the Government of Canada, the provinces
Oral Questions
and the industry for a hearing under chapter 19 of the dispute settlement mechanism. That has been done. We expect that the hearing will commence next month. The process will continue until we get a conclusion.
What Mr. Howlett said and what we say are totally at odds. We are a party to an action under the dispute settlement panel. Mr. Howlett is on the other side of it. Obviously he is going to say everything he can to try to disrupt that process. But the process is proceeding.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary. What the minister just said merely adds to the current uncertainty among softwood lumber manufacturers.
Again, I want to ask the minister whether this question will be subject to chapter 19 of the free trade agreement, and will it be referred to the dispute settlement panel, yes or no?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend had his next question prepared before he heard my answer.
What I said in my response was that we have already filed an application under chapter 19. The application will start being heard next month. It will follow the process from there to a final conclusion, which as I said before we are confident we will be able to win.
What Mr. Howlett said and the facts and the process are completely at odds with each other. He obviously has an axe to grind as the chief spokesman of our opponents on this issue.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister or acting minister of multiculturalism and citizenship.
This morning a unanimous report of the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons recommended that the Court Challenges Program be reinstated. I salute government members of the committee for having the courage to admit that the government made a mistake.

Oral Questions
Will the government accept the advice of this parliamentary committee and reinstate this program?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the program was terminated because initially it was intended to provide a base for the establishment of jurisprudence in a number of cases.
The government felt that had been done and that obviously, in a period of strict budgetary restraint, if the purposes of the program had been fulfilled it might be wise to review that program and abolish it. That is what we did in the last budget.

Mr. Speaker, the unanimous report from the committee does not agree with the minister.
The Court Challenges Program is being forced to close its door in September. The committee's report calls on the government to make a public statement of its intentions within the next 60 calendar days.
Will the minister agree to such a report confirming government support of this program before the program
closes?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (Secretary of State of Canada):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am sure the minister responsible will be looking at the report very closely. Along the lines of our normal procedures the government will respond to the report in due course.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs. It concerns yesterday's decision of the U.S. Supreme Court that makes a mockery of extradition treaties which have been signed by the United States.
In welcoming this decision the United States Attorney General William Barr said: "Our general policy remains co-operation where possible with foreign governments".
Will the minister now send a clear message to the United States government that this Rambo-style, vigilante kidnapping is not acceptable anywhere in the world and that it is a flagrant breach of international law?
Will she immediately seek an exclusionary amendment to the Canada-U.S. extradition treaty to ensure the United States agents can never get away with this in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, Canada was an intervener in the case that led to this decision as it came before the court.
We continue to believe that the appropriate way for U.S. authorities to obtain custody of a criminal suspect is through a request to authorities of other countries, to Canadian authorities for example, under the extradition treaty that exists between our two countries.
Any attempt to abduct someone from Canadian territory we would continue to regard, as we have in the past, as a criminal act.

Mr. Speaker, I wonder how the United States would feel if Canada ignored the treaty, sent the Mounties down to Washington, New York or Kennebunkport, seized an American citizen and brought him back to Canada for trial. I do not think it would accept that and neither should we.
My supplementary question is for the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister now stand up for Canadian sovereignty, tell George Bush that U.S. extradition requests will be put on hold and that not one FBI or DEA agent will set foot on Canadian territory until this monstrous ruling has been overturned?
Will the Secretary of State for External Affairs do the right thing and seek an amendment of the treaty now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this is not a presidential decision. It was a court decision by the Supreme Court. Canada will continue to insist that the extradition treaty in force between Canada and the U.S. is the only method
June 16, 1992

for obtaining the custody of fugitives between our two countries. We will express that in the strongest possible terms.

Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the Secretary of State for External Affairs. I do not feel that the minister's answer is sufficient.
This is an affront to all nations. It allows the United States to come into Canada, abduct Canadian citizens that it suspects of having committed an offence in the United States, and take them back to the United States for trial. It is a complete abandonment of the principles of the extradition treaties.
What I would like to know from the minister is: What is she prepared to do to bring this matter before the World Court for a full and proper hearing?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is very clear that this was a judicial decision in the United States.
I have said that we are going to continue to make our case in the strongest possible way. We have done it in the past; we intervened in a case. We will do so in the future in whatever avenues are open to us.

Mr. Speaker, this is a flagrant abuse of international law. As we speak there are Canadians who are at severe risk.
One such Canadian is Mr. Ken Walker of Richmond Kill who was taken advantage of by the Americans in a sting operation. He is still wanted in the United States although he has not broken any laws.
This morning he called the minister's department and said that he had concern about this ruling. He was told by the minister's department: "We understand your concern. Call your local police". That is a callous response to a man who is in tremendous difficulty as a result of this ruling.
What is the government going to do to protect Canadian sovereignty and the safety of Canadian citizens?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows, and so does Mr. Walker if he wants to get into specific cases, that this government has acted on behalf of Mr. Walker as we have acted on behalf of other Canadians
Oral Questions
who are in difficulty in whatever country they may be in, including the United States.
This is a Supreme Court decision. We will stick by our stand, which the United States does not accept. We will pursue in every avenue we can that extradition is the only way in which to proceed.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
The minister knows certainly that Canadians throughout the country were very disappointed last week when his discussions with the provinces broke off and the minister could not reach a successful conclusion.
I would ask him to give us today in the House a report on the status of the negotiations. Second and more important, what step does he intend to contemplate next to solve the constitutional crisis?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canadians should not be disappointed that the process which yielded so many gains on the constitutional front was not able in that stage to get everything done.
From our point of view, there were four major questions remaining: an agreement on the Senate; an agreement on the amending formula; an agreement on reducing barriers to trade within Canada; and a means to bring us together on the basic questions relating to aboriginal Canadians.
There are ongoing conversations. I am quite encouraged by the people with whom I have been speaking, with their forthcoming nature and particularly the willingness to consider models of Senate reform which may lead us to an agreement on that question.
If the provinces continue to be forthcoming on those issues, we may well be able to get a breakthrough. If I have other plans to report to the House, I will certainly do that.

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the minister for mentioning the four major areas that remain to be finalized.

Oral Questions
I know that many, I would even say most, Quebecers hope that very soon proposals on renewed federalism will be forthcoming that will be acceptable to both the Parliament of Canada and a majority of the provincial legislatures.
My question to the minister is this: Do the areas that remain to be finalized include changes in the amending formula that would give Quebec a veto in the future? Is the minister prepared to give us the assurance that this very important point, which was part of Quebec's original demands, will be respected and that we can expect a positive response from the Canadian government?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
