speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
In
fact, on the basis of our discussions so far, Mr. Speaker, agreement could be reached on an amending formula where the Supreme Court is concerned. This is an important step, and even the premier of Newfoundland and the government of Alberta made it clear they agreed with this proposal.
Two major aspects remain: the Senate and the status of the provinces. I think we would be more likely to reach an agreement on an amending formula once we have agreed on the Senate.
That is why we are now discussing with the provinces a number of formulas that might give us an agreement on the Senate. However, it is up to the provinces to demonstrate their own flexibility and their determination to reach an agreement.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of health. As he well knows, breast cancer is now at almost epidemic proportions. This fact was underscored yesterday in this House with the tabling of a parliamentary committee report on the disease.
I would like to ask the minister again: Will the government consider making increased funding for breast cancer research a priority and will it do that by shifting existing spending?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to say first that the
report tabled yesterday represents very good work. Of course, I have not yet had the time to look at all the recommendations that I want to do.
In terms of breast cancer, we will have to put more emphasis not only on breast cancer but also on other health issues. We are close to getting a report on foetal alcohol syndrome. The Hearn report on medical devices is coming too. We also have the drugs management report by Gagnon. All those reports have something in common: They deal with the health of women.
I would like to say to the House today, after one year as minister of health, I want to consider all issues dealing with the health of women. Those issues have to be seen in a particular perspective and it is that which I want to apply to breast cancer. If there is any way we can put more money toward breast cancer research and it is useful to do so, we will.

Mr. Speaker, this year in Canada over 14,000 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer and 5,000 women will die of it.
The subcommittee tabled its report on breast cancer yesterday. It found that breast cancer research in this country is grossly underfunded. The committee made one particular recommendation, that the federal government allocate $2 million to establish a Canadian breast cancer foundation.
I want to ask the minister of health specifically: Will he implement that recommendation and will he do it immediately?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in light of what I said before,
I believe the member will allow me to consider all of the report and not just answer her recommendation today.
I repeat what I said. I said that if we believe it is the report's position that money is not sufficient in terms of breast cancer research, we will consider that possibility.
I am sure she knows there is no ceiling set in terms of money for research in cancer. It depends on the quality of projects presented to NHRDP or to the Medical Research Council. If we have good projects, I want to Examine the money which is allocated. If we can do something, we will put more money into research for breast cancer.

Mr. Speaker, the fact of the matter is the total allocation in the last budget year for breast cancer research from this government to the MRC was $849,000. That is abysmal and so is the track record of the department on women's health issues. I have mentioned the IUD, thalidomide, Depo-Provera, and breast implants.
Every two hours in Canada another Canadian woman dies from breast cancer. We do not have the time for more reviews. The study has been done. Will the minister implement it?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I repeat what I said. I said that we should consider women's health issues in a different manner than we have so far. It may be that for too long that question has been seen in a man's perspective. I do not disagree with that, but we are saying we will put $1 million toward breast cancer and other health problems with women. I want to look at the options. If there is a necessity to provide more money, we will.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
After the minister's recent visit to Cyprus I am sure it is clear to her and to the government that if Canada withdraws its peacekeeping forces it is going to just help one side and at the same time hurt the other. That is not the basis to encourage a peaceful, just and viable solution to the Cyprus problem.
Will the minister confirm for the House that Canada will not withdraw nor will it reduce its peacekeeping forces on Cyprus until there is a peaceful, just and viable solution?
Will she also confirm for the House that Canada is prepared to apply the same standard of support for the UN Cyprus resolutions as it was prepared to apply for the United Nations Kuwait resolutions?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in dealing with the Cyprus issue it would be very difficult to make a
Oral Questions
commitment that we would stay until there is a negotiated settlement.
We have been in Cyprus for 28 years. We are very encouraged at the moment by the progress being made. Part of this is a result of having pointed out to the Secretary General earlier this winter that the Secretary General and the parties involved had a responsibility to come to a peaceful solution and Canada would not make a commitment to be there forever. Even the patience of Canadians runs out.
We are encouraged by the progress that has been made since then and with the changes going on in that region, with some of the parties involved, and how their interests are reflected.
We think the forthcoming discussions will be useful in making progress in Cyprus. We encourage the Secretary General to continue and also the parties involved to accept their responsibility for peace among their people in their region.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday, the Minister of Communications quoted observations made by the chairman of the CFTC and me on competition among telephone companies, but he did not take a position or answer questions on behalf of his government. I repeat my question concerning consumers:
Is the minister prepared to assure us that the CRTC's decisions will have no negative impact on consumers and on residential customers and that local rates will not go up? Yes or no.
Good question.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend raises the question of the position of consumers with regard to the CRTC decision. I suppose the best source might be Mr. David Simpson, the executive director of the Consumers' Association of Canada who said: "We could have written this decision ourselves it came so close to what business and consumers were looking for". This is from the spokesman on behalf of the Consumers' Association of Canada.

June 16, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I guess the minister has not been able to think about what he would like to say for himself and his government. I would like to ask him a supplementary.
Because this government has failed to pass legislation that will guarantee 80 per cent Canadian ownership and control of domestic telephone companies, including resellers, there is a threat of Americanization of our system since the CRTC opened up new areas of competition.
Given that the minister has made sovereignty a key policy of his new legislation, will he now move to pass those sections of Bill C-62 that will safeguard Canadian ownership of this key economic sector?

Mr. Speaker, I will go even further than that. I very much appreciate the endorsement by the Liberal Party of Canada of Bill C-62. I think we should not just pass certain sections of the bill but we should pass the whole bill as quickly as possible.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Minister of National Defence.
For a long time rumours have been flying around fast and furious to the effect that the Emergency Preparedness Canada training centre was going to be moved out of the town of Amprior.
Last week the Minister of Supply and Services, our regional minister, clarified the situation by stating in a letter that the training centre will remain in Amprior.
Will the Minister of the National Defence tell us today when we can expect the construction of the long-promised new residential building to be built at Amprior?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, in the latest budget, all responsibilities for civil defence were transferred to the Department of National Defence. All procedures, including infrastructure, are under review.

Mr. Speaker, my next question is for the Minister of Public Works.
The property and facilities on which this nationally used Emergency Preparedness Canada training centre is located is the property of Public Works Canada.
Can the minister inform this House whether or not the total plans for the new residential building, which was supposed to be up and operating by December 1990, are now ready for presentation to Treasury Board and are they planned for Amprior?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the whole question is covered in the first answer.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister who signed on behalf of Canada the convention for climate change at the earth summit. It regrettably contains no targets or timetables for reductions.
Since Canada publicly committed to stabilize all greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2000 in Geneva almost two years ago, would the Prime Minister tell this House what Canada's emissions were in 1990 so that Canadians can know what that means by the year 2000?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the hon. member knows that work has been undertaken to make a determination on the baseline level of information that will be the object of some discussion at the next meeting of the Canadian Council of the Ministers of Environment which will be held sometime next November.
I should also point out to the hon. member that the Prime Minister indicated not only would Canada sign the treaty but we would also ratify it within the year. We would also encourage other countries to enter into a prompt start process by which we could go out there and apply the dispositions of the treaty.
June 16, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is to the Prime Minister who also signed the convention on biodiversity to protect plants and animals.
Would the Prime Minister tell this House what steps will be taken to protect the 227 endangered species of wildlife in Canada, a whopping 13 per cent increase since last year, that are on the brink of extinction? What is the Prime Minister going to do for the short-homed lizard, the phantom orchid, the white-headed woodpecker or the High Arctic beluga whale? Anything?

Mr. Speaker, given my hon. friend's interest in the environment and his presence in Brazil, I thought that he would have wanted to invite the House to join in a very genuine round of applause for the Minister of the Environment for his tremendous leadership.
Hear, hear.

This was clearly an oversight by my hon. friend. He mentioned the endangered species, which range from the beluga whale to the NDP, I suppose.
My friend raises a very serious question. The Minister of the Environment has indicated that the government is participating in post-Rio conferences with specific plans to deal precisely with the very legitimate question raised by my hon. friend.
I think that as he participates in these post-Rio conferences, initiated by Canada, he will feel the same sense of pride that he did in Rio as he watched the Minister of the Environment and other parliamentarians guide the Canadian delegation, I think quite successfully* * *

I wish to draw to the attention of hon. members the presence in the gallery of the Hon. Gilbert R. Clements, Minister of the Environment and Minister of Finance for the province of Prince Edward Island.

Hear, hear.
Supply

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, during Question Period, in answering a question by the hon. member for Yukon, I used the words "intelligent question".
This did not translate what I actually meant. I do not want to impute that the hon. member is not an intelligent person. I should have used the word "pertinent". That is what I meant. If I caused any heartache, or whatever, to the hon. member I wish to apologize.
The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Loiselle (p. 12117).

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: At the suspension of the debate at one o'clock there were seven minutes left in the question or comments period. The hon. member for Annapolis Valley-Hants had the floor.

Mr. Speaker, after the very eloquent address this morning of the hon. member for Renfrew-Nipissing-Pembroke, I was directing a question to him when time ran out just as I was posing the question.
Since we both came here many moons ago in the class of '65, and although there were some younger members honoured yesterday because of the class of '68, I was calling upon him to give his views-perhaps not necessarily those of his party, but from his own parliamentary experience-as to the state of the constitutional discussions. Does he see a danger in trying to come up with some type of an agreement? It might not find favour all across the country, and may not be in a form where it can be presented to the time clock that is ticking in Quebec.

Supply
From his point of view, what would happen, because Quebec has that law that there has to be a referendum in Quebec, if that referendum proceeds on a very clear question as to whether Quebec wants to stay in Canada-and of course we do not frame that question-and what would be his view if that question proceeded on the basis that we cannot put an agreement to Quebec before that October deadline?

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has asked me if I would put forward my views even though they may not be the views of my party.
I want to say to him that any views I give are those of my own party and vice versa because I do have my say within our party caucus and discuss the matter with my caucus members. I do not go off giving views that do not belong to the Liberal Party of Canada. That is called unity and that is what we are talking about in this entire debate.
To address the several questions which the member has just put to me, I want to say that if I were to give him the answer the minister opposite, who is handling the constitutional questions at the present time and federal-provincial relations, would really thank me for giving him the precise answers. If I were to come up with all the answers for the government at this time I would probably be the most famous Canadian going.
To ask me to tell everybody else what is going to happen in the days ahead is a little bit unfair because if we had the answers we would be going in that direction.
I said in my speech this morning that the rhetoric has to be toned down on this issue. I also said that the demands have to be toned down from all angles and that flexibility must improve across the country.
Parliament could be recalled this summer-the option is open-and we could debate the constitutional proposals or whatever. We could also be here to discuss whether or not we are having a referendum. But to say that if I had the answers I could give them now, anything else that I might say would disrupt the very sensitivity of the items that are being discussed now.
The member mentioned our long tenure here in Parliament. My long tenure in Parliament tells me not to disrupt an already sensitive situation. What I have said is that we must have the political will and the determination to handle this situation. This morning I said there is
no such thing as failure. I also said that every person in this House, on both sides of this House, must make it their business to see to it that the constitutional issue is settled and that we can get on with the economy and the other great interests of this nation.
Let me remind everybody that there is far more to lose by standing aloof and making great demands of our own by individual groups or organizations than there ever will be to gain.
All Canadians and this Parliament must come together. We are a nation known as negotiators. We now have to negotiate to put this Constitution together and we are not going to do it if we are going to go off in 10 different directions at the same time. Now is the time to prove our mettle.
I want to say once more, in reply to the hon. member, as I said this morning, that 112,000 young Canadians are lying in cemeteries abroad, in Korea and throughout Europe, 18, 19, 21 and 24 years of age. They fought for this country and they fought for the free world. If we do not come to grips and unite this nation at this time as did the Fathers of Confederation, the Baldwins, the Lafon-taines, the Georges-Etienne Cartiers and the Macdonalds, and all those great statesmen who followed on in the 20th century, then we are not only failing those
112,000	young Canadians who died in the name of freedom, we are losing faith with those who built this country in the beginning.
I say to members on both sides of the House and to the hon. member who asked me the question: We must have the political will to face up to this issue, to sit down and negotiate and bring the Constitution of Canada into fruition for years to come. We have the ability to do it. We must not lose it.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to have the opportunity to enter into debate today on the motion to concur in the Main Estimates of the government, the spending estimates of the government.
It gives me an opportunity to raise a number of concerns in this House about issues across the country and in particular around some of the particular spending plans or lack of spending plans by the Government of Canada as they relate to my riding in northern British Columbia.
June 16, 1992

It is a good opportunity to do that today. The minister of forests is encouraging me to mention forestry in a few comments which of course I will be pleased to do. I would do that in encouragement to the minister. I know he is going to hang on my every word today about the importance of forestry to our area.
There are a couple of areas I would like to mention. I am pleased that the minister is here because a couple of the issues affect the community for which we share representation. I know he will be taking notes. I hope he will follow up on these as I have already done to the minister in writing.
In particular on forestry, just a bit of a nudge to the minister. He knows there have been discussions in Prince George regarding the Forestry of Canada Research Centre located in Prince George currently on the federal government experimental farm which unfortunately, from the federal government's point of view, through attrition and cuts and transfers really is being slowly chopped away to the point where most unfortunately we may lose a real presence by the federal government in terms of a role in agricultural policy and research. There have been many transfers of officials to Kamloops.
I am afraid we are going to reach a point in this operation where to some degree the government is going to say there is nothing left. It will then be in a position where it will have to close the whole shop down. That would be most unfortunate.
I know the minister is aware of that. He is aware of it from a departmental point of view as well, given the location on the experimental farm site near the airport in Prince George and the discussions I have had, and I know he has had, about attempting to relocate that facility to the new campus of the University of B.C. where I was pleased to attend the sod-tuming with Premier Harcourt and of course the first convocation of the newest university in Canada. The minister of forests was present as well.
That is really great news for Prince George and the whole region of northern British Columbia. It is important because of what the minister's department can do in making a contribution to the operation of that university. I am talking specifically about the transfer of the Forestry Canada operations now on the experimental farm to the university site. There is a close co-operation
Supply
that can be held with the collection of research capability and learning at the campus and also of course with the project locating right nearby which the minister has been to as well, Forests for the World, which is a display of the different tree species we have in the area. It gives the public an opportunity really to come and see just what having a forest operation is. It is located near the campus. I would urge the government and the minister to move as quickly as possible in making an announcement that we can have that Forestry Canada operation, small as it is, moved to the campus site.
The minister had appointed a committee and had promised to report some months ago. I have written to the minister to ask for more details on that and as to when we might get a decision. It is very important. It goes to the heart of what we are talking about here today. It is not grand schemes of a constitution. We are really talking about the nitty-gritty of government, some of the very basic spending plans that government can have in our ridings. I mention that as one of them.
As well, the minister should be tabling soon I hope a state of the forest report flowing from the legislation to create his department. Also, Mr. Speaker, you know as well as I do that we have expressed our concerns in this House before about the government's cuts to forestry programs across the country. I think of the FRDA program in British Columbia, which is a concern to all of us. We do not see Forestry Canada removing itself as a player in terms of co-operation that it can play with the provinces in forest renewal, in forest management. In particular following the world summit in Rio on the environment, it is all the more important that we maintain a presence, I argue, in terms of Forestry Canada. I know that is a subject of some debate and discussion on the Constitution.
I hope that in the final analysis when a discussion is held about whether we are going to have a forest department that the premiers, the Prime Minister and this House do not just throw out the work of many of us in our first days here as parliamentarians to bring forward legislation in this House to create that department. I would argue that there is probably a need today more than ever, given our demands on our forests from an international environmental perspective, for a federal forest department.

Supply
I hope at the very least in the discussions that some heed is paid to that particular issue during the constitutional debate and the debate that we are going to end up having in this House on that issue.
There is another spending issue that relates directly to forests and ties in directly with the work or the lack of it I suppose by the Minister for International Trade. That comes to the whole question of the softwood tariff dispute we have now with the United States. As you know, Mr. Speaker, I led a delegation of New Democrat MPs from the interior of British Columbia as well as my colleague from Thunder Bay in northern Ontario to Washington to meet with American legislators and officials on this issue. I think it was a very important two days. We delivered a strong message to the Americans about Canada and about our view on this issue.
We have some well known differences with this government's approach to this whole issue, but on the question of the softwood dispute we gave a united message to the Americans. I say that Canadians want to ensure that from this government they get the same message as well.
I have said on numerous occasions that it is important that we keep pressure on our own government. It is a pretty clear perception among most Canadians that this government just rolls over and plays dead whenever George Bush and the Commerce Department in Washington, D.C. basically tells it what to do. We found that in this dispute, whereas yet we have not heard a formal word from the United States, the Commerce Department or the Bush administration as to whether this whole softwood dispute can even be referred to this much vaunted dispute settlement mechanism that the minister of trade so often talks about. It is revealing of the weakness of the free trade agreement that even after three years of operation this government still has to plead with Washington, D.C. for this whole dispute to be settled by even a weak dispute settlement mechanism, which it is.
We have not heard the end of that yet. We may end up having a dispute over the dispute settlement of all things. It gives an indication of how much trouble we are in with this dispute. We are on the verge of perhaps the most massive trade dispute in Canadian history between our two governments. It is over an issue that is of critical
importance, not just to the entire country but in particular to British Columbia which makes some 80 per cent of the softwood lumber exports to the United States.
Another issue I have raised throughout my riding and in different parts of the country is an important issue for many of the smaller communities in this country. In many cases we have to plead with different levels of government to get the kinds of services and programs we need. In many cases larger centres across the country take so much for granted. I guess I am reminded of that each day here in Ottawa where, of course, we would expect our nation's capital to have those kinds of buildings and monuments to our country and to the history of this area. However, at the same time, let us not forget the contribution made by the rural communities, the resource communities across the country. Yes, they are away from the major population centres, but they are just as deserving when it comes to government services and programs.
I am reminded in particular of a case where we were pleased to have convinced the Minister of Communications to provide some funds for an art gallery in Prince George. I would like to encourage the government to go a step further. We have to take a look at using some of the funds under the communications subagreement to help with the art gallery in Prince George.
In the election campaign in 1988 the previous government clearly rejected any federal help for a performing arts centre in Prince George. I have collected information since that election. I have been diligent at this because it was my sense that this government had spent millions of dollars elsewhere across the country on similar ventures but, of course, gave the cold shoulder to Prince George. Tb date that evidence shows that some $143 million in projects similar to that which we have been lobbying and working for in Prince George has been spent and authorized by this government, ranging from the Comedy Museum in Montreal. I have nothing against a good joke or project but we are just asking for our fair share.
I ask that the government give serious consideration to those proposals because that is the kind of nitty-gritty work the Government of Canada can do to show Canadians and residents of these communities that small communities are as deserving as any major population centre for the kinds of projects which bestow pride on a community for the work they have done.
June 16, 1992

We had a healthy contribution from the new Government of British Columbia for the Civic Centre complex in Prince George. That was announced on Friday. We are pleased with that. This government is prepared to spend billions of dollars on helicopters for which there is some question as to their need and yet a community that needs an art gallery and what have you is given the cold shoulder by this government. That is not good enough. We deserve and expect more.
As well there are a couple of transportation matters that are critical to ridings line mine in northern British Columbia where transportation is an important issue because of our location. I am pleased to have been able to work with community groups and others.
There is a new instrument landing system being put into Prince George, a project costing around $2 million. I am pleased to have been able to do that but we have more work to do, and I think of air strips outside of the Prince George area where in some cases we cannot even get a medivac jet in to take someone out.
If members from large urban communities would not be able to get an ambulance they would be shocked by that, yet that is what we have in many of these communities. The government has to make a commitment to provide the necessary infrastructure and programs necessary to provide these services to Canadians regardless of where we live in the country.
The finance minister at least alluded to that at the first ministers' meeting in Toronto on the economy some time ago. Prior to that he mentioned that the government has tucked away somewhere a capital projects fund.
I have written to the minister. I would like to find out a little bit about this fund. How much money does the Minister of Finance have tucked away somewhere? Is he going to spend it all in the run-up to the next election campaign as the Prime Minister was to apt to do prior to the last election campaign? Let us get some details on that capital projects fund. Let us make it public so we can see what is available and at least give communities across the country an opportunity to make representations to the minister for funds from that project.

One of those infrastructure programs on which I have been corresponding with the Minister of Finance, the Minister of Transport and the British Columbia minister of transport is the Yellowhead Highway program, which we used to have. It was a program that helped upgrade the Yellowhead Highway from my colleague's riding, Skeena, through my riding in Prince George-Bulkley Valley and down into the Kamloops area, represented by another of my colleagues.
That program was allowed to collapse and run out by this government and by the former government in British Columbia. I asked this minister in this government on behalf of the people along that highway and on behalf of the minister of transport for British Columbia, who has asked us to make representations to the government, to go ahead and hopefully renew that program.
At the earlier First Ministers' Conference that I mentioned, the Minister of Finance hinted at a national highways network. When a Minister of Finance is hinting at something like that we should take him up on it. However it is his turn, we have taken him up on the offer to renew this program. I now want to hear from the minister and this government whether they really are committed to an infrastructure program that can help rebuild those transportation arteries which we require all across the country.
I hope that before this House rises for its summer break the minister can make that kind of announcement to give some assurance to Canadians and the people in northern B.C. that this very important transportation link has the attention of the Government of Canada and will be dealt with, approved, and renewed in the near future.
I mentioned airports and air transportation. I mentioned highways, and the unique federal role in this particular issue, one which I do not think is thought of much in western Canada. When I drive on any of the roads in eastern Canada I note that there is significant federal presence in working with the provinces in highway reconstruction. We just ask for the same in northern British Columbia. I do not think it is asking too much for this government to treat one end of the country the same as the other.

I would like to conclude with an appeal to the government to please make up its mind about VIA Rail remote services. There is a run from Prince Rupert to Prince George to Jasper. This government said on October 4, 1989 that it would make a decision on this run. It has been announcing that it would be soon making decisions on this. We have been patient while waiting for the government to make a decision.
I appeal to the Minister of Transport and the government to make up their minds as soon as possible. Do not sit around and wait. We do not want to wait for an election campaign for good news, we will take the good news announcements now. I ask the government to get off whatever royal seat the government is on and make up its mind about this very important issue in our area.
It is an opportunity to provide that valuable transportation link. I have used this opportunity in the House to raise a number of important issues concerning the nitty-gritty of government spending and planning. I hope the government will take heed of some of these measures and make some positive announcements for all of us. It is a case of many communities asking and fighting for their fair share.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to make some comments on the 1992-93 Main Estimates for Agriculture Canada.
I would like to begin by presenting a few facts about the agrifood industry. In Canada, agriculture and food and beverage processing contributes some $50 billion to the economy every year. Food processing is the second largest component in Canadian manufacturing after automobiles, and the agrifood sector accounts for about 10 per cent of our total exports.
These are impressive figures that clearly demonstrate the importance of the agrifood sector to all Canadians. However, in this 125th year of Confederation Canada's agrifood producers are facing some of the greatest challenges in the industry's history.
The world economy is growing increasingly globalized and interdependent. New trading blocs are forming and more and more countries are entering the international marketplace.
The opportunities for Canada in this environment are enormous. Already an exporting country, we have the natural resources, the human resources and the technology to build on our strong trading base. However, if our agrifood producers are going to capitalize on these advantages they must move quickly to diversify and become more efficient and more competitive. They must adopt new technologies, new methods and new ways of thinking and doing business. They must put more emphasis on research and promotion, seek out new market opportunities and form new partnerships at home and abroad. They must begin to look much more closely at the long-term sustainability of the sector environmentally, economically and socially. They must do this in a time of continuing restraint, increasing competition and ongoing international trade wars.
In 1989, in an effort to help the industry adapt to changing realities, Agriculture Canada undertook the agrifood policy review in consultation with the provinces and the industry stakeholders. The review is based on four major pillars of reform: market responsiveness, regional sensitivity, self-reliance and environmental sustainability.
There has already been significant progress toward these goals. For example, the new safety net programs, GRIP and NISA, are designed to encourage greater self-reliance on the part of agricultural producers and greater income predictability.
The three-year National Farm Business Management Program announced in March is designed to increase farm business management training and to make more business information and consulting services available to farmers. The check-off legislation now before the Senate would encourage greater research and promotion by agricultural producers.
In 1992-93 Agriculture Canada's priorities will be to continue to build on the work of the policy review, to encourage continued adaptation and greater competitiveness in the agrifood sector, and to ensure improved government responsiveness to the changing needs of the industry.
The department will be working to build more effective, efficient and regionally sensitive partnerships with the provinces and the industry stakeholders.
June 16, 1992

It helps the primary and processing sectors improve their competitiveness and provides farmers with the information, services and training they need to improve their business management skills.
It helps the agrifood industry pursue new diversification opportunities; and helps maintain and develop domestic and international markets for our products through trade policy, marketing support, research and responsive regulations.
It promotes the environmental sustainability of the Canadian agrifood industry and the safety and quality of Canada's food supply.
Finally, it enhances corporate and organizational structures to better enable Agriculture Canada employees to provide quality service in response to the changing needs of the department's clients.
The federal budget contains a number of provisions which should help with these efforts. For example, the tax exemption for ethanol and methanol in gasoline blends will encourage the development and use of ethanol and methanol fuels made from feed stocks. This will not only lead to considerable new market opportunities for grain producers, it will also help to protect the environment and encourage increased producer involvement in value-added processing.
The Small Business Financing Program, which will run until the end of 1992, will help small family farm businesses in difficulty obtain loans at lower interest rates.
Tax reductions to Canadian manufacturers and processors will help to improve the competitiveness of food processors and farm input suppliers such as machinery manufacturers.
The review of Agriculture Canada regulations, in partnership with provinces and industry, will ensure that federal regulations are helping, not hindering industry adaptation.
As well, through the agrifood policy review, the department will be continuing its efforts to build a second generation of supply management and to ensure the efficiency of our transportation systems.
Through agreements like GATT and NAFTA, it will continue to work toward a more liberal and predictable
Supply
international trading environment with more equitable trading rules.
The department also recognizes the need to continue to support our agricultural producers over the short term. Agriculture Canada's Main Estimates for 1992-93 total about $2.9 billion. Of this, more than $1.2 billion is being paid for GRIP and NISA and for the farms support and adjustment measure initiatives, FSAM I and FSAM II.
In the year ahead, the department will focus on improving safety net programs so that they do more to encourage industry adaptation. For instance, the provisions in FSAM I to encourage participation in GRIP and NISA are a good example of how income support spending can be used to foster greater self-reliance by agricultural producers. I would also like to note that governments are committed to extending NISA eligibility to the whole farm program.
Combined with the efforts of the federal government to stimulate economic growth through low inflation and interest rates, these initiatives should go a long way toward relieving the pressures on Canada's agrifood sector.
In fact, the 1991 census of agriculture shows that, despite the difficult economic times over the last year, we are already seeing some progress.
The census reported increased acres under cultivation since 1986, an increase in livestock production and more acreage dedicated to specialty crops, a sign that farmers are beginning to diversify.
As well, farmers are increasingly adopting more environmentally sustainable practices, with reduced use of chemicals and increased use of conservation tillage.
The 1992 survey of farms shows that farmers largely thought they were holding their ground financially. Some 48 per cent said their situation was the same, 13 per cent said the financial picture was better; and 38 per cent said things were worse.
In comparison, in the 1990 survey 43 per cent said their situation was the same and only 11 per cent said it was better. Some 45 per cent said their situation was worse than the year before, 6 per cent more than in the most recent survey.

June 16, 1992
Supply
The results show that farmers are more optimistic about the future. In 1990, 34 per cent thought their situation would stay the same, 19 per cent felt it would improve, and 39 per cent felt it would get worse.
In the 1991 survey 44 per cent thought things would stay the same, 25 per cent thought their situation would improve, and 23 per cent were pessimistic about the coming year.
More concrete signs of improvement can be seen in the grains and oilseeds sector which has been the hardest hit by the international subsidy wars. Wheat exports are 34 per cent higher at this point in the crop year than they were last year. Sales through the west coast have hit records every month except September.
Due to tightening world wheat supplies, especially in the United States, and greater demand from the former U.S.S.R. and China, world wheat prices have risen since the crop year began. This has resulted in higher Canadian Wheat Board initial payments. As well, we have seen higher initial payments for feed barley, designated barley and durum wheat.
I am confident that with the co-operation of all governments and with strong industry leadership we will continue to see improvements in the economic position of the agrifood industry in the years ahead.

Mr. Speaker, I was very interested in the comments on agriculture of the hon. member for Elgin-Norfolk. I completely agree with him that there is a tremendous need for research and development in the food processing industry. If we lose the food processing industry, we lose the market for those producers.
Clearly that is one of the greatest challenges facing us with the free trade deal with the United States. There are no offsets. There is no protection as there was in the free trade deal for automobiles signed back in the sixties. Essentially we are just reducing the tariffs on processed products.
The agriculture competitiveness council recognized this in a report which it put out in January of this year. It said that we need more research, that we need to upgrade the equipment we have in the food processing industry, and that we were in a deathly competitive world with producers in Mexico, with producers in the United States, with producers in Ireland, and with producers in
other countries. It emphasized the need for increased commitment by the government.
When we look over the 1992-93 estimates of the Department of Agriculture, we see that scientific research and development has been cut by 4 per cent or $11.4 million in 1992-93. Although the hon. member is talking about the right things, his government is doing the wrong things because its cutting back agricultural scientific research by 4 per cent.
If we add the 2 per cent, 3 per cent, or 4 per cent inflation that we face we see an effective cutback of probably 7 per cent or 8 per cent.
It is interesting that just before these estimates came down the Minister of Finance brought down his budget. In the agriculture competitiveness council report of January of this year, which was released slightly thereafter, it talked about the importance of the agrifood processing industry. It said that if Canada did not act immediately, if Canada did not provide very significant incentives to encourage investment in productivity enhancing activities in the agrifood sector, we would lose out. It recommended that we increase the capital cost allowance from 25 per cent to 50 per cent.
When the Minister of Finance brought in his budget he brought in a piddling 5 per cent increase. This is to save an industry of which he was the minister.
I would like to ask the member: Why is the government cutting scientific research? Why is it only providing a 5 per cent increase when the government's own agriculture competitiveness council recommended a 25 per cent increase? Why is there a cutback in agricultural research when its own competitiveness council was recommending that there be a massive increase of 200 per cent in current tax depreciation and research as recommended by its agriculture competitiveness council?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend for his comments and his question. He will recognize that the policy review undertaken by the Department of Agriculture, by the former Minister of Agriculture, pointed to some of the things he has talked about: about further processing of products in Canada, not only in agriculture but other aspects of natural resources, so that we might create jobs in Canada and create that extra wealth for Canadians. I believe that is the direction the government is taking.

The hon. member talked about research and development. He thinks there have been cuts. I would tend to think that if the hon. member really took a look at it he would recognize that those dollars being spent on research and development by the federal government are under review. They will be put to greater use in the future to make sure that those dollars are wisely spent. We recognize we have to spend dollars in research and development. That is what the Minister of Finance was aiming at with his reduction in the federal budget.
I am sure the hon. member will also recognize the competitive council, in its discussions with Canadians across Canada, talked about the various things that might need some looking at such as the regulations which three departments, including the Department of Agriculture, have already started. It recognized that we needed to take a look at some of the regulations to make sure we were not hindering processing or further development in Canada.
The hon. member will recognize that the government looks at over-all expenditures. We are acting in a responsible way, trying to make sure those dollars spent are spent in a super controlled way so that we do not increase the deficit and end up with the problems we had when we took over the government in 1984.
Mr. Speaker, our side has agreed among ourselves to limiting debate to 10 minutes so that two speakers could be heard in the 20 minutes, starting with me.

Mr. Speaker, our twinning of the two ridings seems to be going very well. The students who returned from Your Honour's riding last week had nothing but praise for the reception they received. I hope when your students come back to our area under the 125 celebration we will be able to host them in the same way and to continue that program.
I rise today to talk a bit about the government's estimates, not necessarily estimates in terms of specific items as much as in terms of government spending. Our
Supply
party before the budget and since the budget has put forward to the government the idea of creating jobs by putting money into infrastructure that is needed right across Canada.
Once again, I have to ask the government to see that this idea has merit. It can create jobs. It can get Canada moving again. As we look at our infrastructure, sewers, roads and various other types of infrastructure in different communities, we see what is needed to keep Canada at a certain level of ability to perform.
I know these are difficult economic times. I would just say there are probably areas this government could look at. One would be in the administration of the UI funds in terms of putting money into creating jobs rather than having to spend it on unemployment insurance or welfare rolls.
I do not see this happening. I see despair out there as to when the economy is going to turn around. When are we going to be able to use the low interest rates we have seen come down so slowly over the last while? They are down, yet the businesses are not picking up, at least in the rural areas. There does not seem to be hope or the new ideas with which the research and development we used to have in Canada might have created new jobs.
We saw in the budget the decrease in research and development. Over the years the government has cut back the Economic Council, the Law Reform Commission and the Science Council of Canada. All these areas have given greatly to Canada. I know members opposite will say that we can go somewhere else and get this research done. I heard it here this morning. Yes, we can probably go to the Americans as usual and ask for their statistics. They do not always apply to Canada because we have different values from the Americans, different values for what we feel in Canada has made us Canadian.
I want to raise another idea today. When I took part in the debate earlier I said that we have excess in our ministers' departments. We have excess in their staff and we have excess in people overseeing groups. The chief of staff who is highly paid, paid higher than a member of Parliament or higher than his minister, is he the same as the deputy minister or the assistant deputy minister? I do not understand why we need all these layers to produce something.

June 16, 1992
Supply
A very innocent example was given today in the House during Question Period. Yesterday we had an all-party report on breast cancer. The three parties agreed that cancer causes death: 5,000 women will die and 14,000 women will have breast cancer in Canada this year. These are real statistics. We do not need more studies to say that we need more research to prevent these senseless deaths from occurring in Canada.
If it were a man who had the same problem, it would probably be passed and we would not even have to ask about it in the House. It seems so ironic that the mothers of our children, the women out there today, have to live with an idea that more studies have to be done to tell the Department of National Health and Welfare that it would be a good idea to start putting some of its dollars into this, particularly when it says it has a ceiling with no limit.
I also want to raise the issue of CFB Cornwallis.
Over the last year I have seen the continuous reduction of jobs in my area. I do not have great companies in my area. I do not have ACOA that can find multitudes of businesses to bring into the area or a multitude of businesses to expand in my area. We do have CFB Cornwallis and it has provided jobs continuously for all my lifetime in that area. It has worked very effectively. It is in a cost-effective area. The taxes are not high, land is cheap, we have a ready-made harbour and ready-made facilities for any naval training. We have an airport and we have CFB Greenwood, which can work in conjunction with CFB Cornwallis. There are many reasons why CFB Cornwallis should be an ideal place for the Armed Forces.
Yet we have seen a reduction of jobs, with a further reduction of about 100 jobs contemplated within the next few weeks. We have seen businesses close and the threat of school closures. People who have been employed for years may have to face very tough times and leave their homes and area. This threat has been hanging over the people in the area for well over a year and a half.
What does CFB Cornwallis do and why is it important to the Armed Forces? Since 1968 all new recruits who
speak English have been trained at CFB Cornwallis. I realize the Minister of National Defence has said as of last September the Canadian Armed Forces would be reduced to 75,000 for regular Armed Forces. This was in light of the conditions in the world, and I can quite accept that. But where are those 75,000 enlisted men going to be trained? My people are asking me where they are going.
I tell them we have the ideal facilities. We have been training since 1968. I do not know why we cannot be reassured it is going to continue, and we will be able to train new recruits for the Armed Forces across Canada. We can do militia, cadets, reserves, and we have done other training there over the years.
People look to Parliament to see what decisions are going to be made and if their future is protected. New recruits coming in from Alberta or Newfoundland want to know there is a place for them in the Armed Forces. Yet, apparently there are no new recruits coming into the Armed Forces because of whatever the policy is.
It is my understanding at the end of this month we will lose our base commander and a lieutenant-colonel will come in. It means the status of the base for new recruits will be reduced to a station. Those who have had a military base in their constituency know that somehow the government has failed to find something to put into CFB Cornwallis along with new recruits. I say that because our area is a bilingual constituency and we have a bilingual university. My people and I see no reason why we could not be training all new recruits in Canada. Certainly I cannot see why we would be even thinking of moving the English speaking new recruits anywhere else in Canada.
I have to voice these concerns to the House because we have had something and we see it slowly being lost through the reduction of jobs, the closing down of businesses, the threat of school closures and even hospitals. We have to ask ourselves if closing means when there is only one person left, then we close the area. If that is so, it is very cruel and unusual punishment to inflict.
June 16, 1992

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Perhaps I may add just a few words. I would like to respond to the cordial remarks made by the hon. member for South West Nova and stress the superb co-operation between our two ridings, as a result of which residents of both ridings will be visiting each other this summer to create a brotherhood of Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I listened with a great deal of interest to my colleague, the member for South West Nova, which is adjacent to my riding of Annapolis Valley-Hants. I represented the riding of Annapolis Valley-Digby Annapolis-Cains, as it was called when I was first elected many moons ago and Cornwallis was very much a part of my responsibility. I certainly share the concerns she expressed here in a pretty objective way about what is happening to Cornwallis through attrition and/or ministerial decree, notwithstanding the fact there evidently is a committee on base consolidation and closures that is supposed to make recommendations.
Now we have had another statement from that committee. It is going to postpone fundamental decisions, perhaps until after the next election. I know and come from Nova Scotia too. We have had a history of servicing the services because we are never going to have the massive industries of other parts of the country. That has been part of our history and the pending closure of Cornwallis flies in the face of that.
I would like to ask the member how she feels this base closure committee is really performing. How can it objectively assess the criteria when the minister openly says there are going to be a lot more changes because only 17 per cent of the defence budget is being spent in Quebec? There are going to be changes in other parts of the country regardless of history, to make sure that is redressed. Does she feel this is the sword of Damocles hanging over the base at Cornwallis and the future is no brighter than the hon. member painted it in her remarks?

Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague from Annapolis Valley-Hants for his question. He expresses the concern of my constituents I run into every day as to why this is happening at CFB Cornwallis and soon to be CFS Cornwallis I guess. I have to agree, we are now going to have an infrastructure rationalization process in the ministry of national defence to look at the determined force requirements, determine infrastructure requirements and identify surplus infrastructure. That is what this MAGDI, Ministers' Advisory Group of Defence Infrastructure, said it would be doing.
I find it quite unique in the sense we are giving the Department of National Defence something I think we have never actually given up as parliamentarians, which was the exact role of National Defence in Canada. It is all right for the Department of National Defence to say what may be excess or why, but I do not think anybody should be allowed to say something is a certain way without looking at the effects it has on the community. That must be put into perspective at the Department of National Defence. The defence people are going to make the study and the decisions. At the same time the minister has said openly in committee 17 per cent is not enough of the defence budget for Quebec.
At the same time I know my people are asking why a new naval reserve is going up when we have all the facilities at CFB Cornwallis. Perhaps they are not being given the right answers. They are not being looked at. There seems to be a real dichotomy between the minister and where he sees defence going, and the Department of National Defence in its infrastructure rationalization without looking at economic realities. It could be one general prefers to have something over another general and that is who is going to have his case put before the Minister of National Defence to be reviewed. Parliament will have 30 sitting days to review and no more whenever the decision of the minister's review panel, which comes after the infrastructure rationalization process does it at defence. They are given to the minister. The minister looks at the proposals. He gives them to a review panel. The review panel hands them back to the minister. He then looks at the proposals and they come to Parliament.

Supply
By that time this great study says, get the people used to thinking they are not going to have something and then two years later you can do it.
I am saying it is not a fair way to treat Canadians. It is one thing to say you have to have an even distribution of defence dollars across Canada and that can be done perhaps in capital spending.
But we will never have tank cars built in Nova Scotia in the Annapolis Valley unless somebody decides to put a factory there with a lot of money because the centre of activity is in Ontario.
Surely we can train new recruits in the Canadian Armed Forces. We are going to have at least 50,000 enlisted men and they have to go somewhere to be trained. Why can it not be at Cornwallis? Why can this minister not give that commitment to not only South West Nova but to all Canadians?
It is the most cost-effective way. There is no way you can show me a less cost-effective way of spending our training dollars than at CFB Cornwallis.

Mr. Speaker, the purpose of the debate today is to indicate whether or not a member is supportive of the government's expenditure plan for 1992-93.1 rise in the House to indicate the reasons why I oppose the expenditure plan and in particular reference to Winnipeg.
Members of the House will know that in the last decade Winnipeg has had a particularly difficult time. In the first part of this decade, from 1979-80 right through to the 1984 election, both Liberal members from Winnipeg stood up and worked very hard on behalf of the city.
Subsequent to that, the strategy of the federal government has been to pull out one support after another from our city. As a consequence, an expenditure plan this year does not show what can be done for Winnipeg.
The core area initiative, the most public of programs, the one in which most of us came to identify with a more optimistic future, a game plan for the city, has been taken away. It was not renewed at the end of this year when the opportunity presented itself to the federal Minister of Energy, who represents the federal government at the table.
A few weeks ago all of us watched great difficulties in our cities, from Toronto to L.A. Those of us who have downtown constituencies know the frustration felt by
youth, families and the elderly as they found the city unsafe.
The one thing that distinguishes North American Liberals from North American Conservatives is whether or not we should sit back and allow this to happen, whether or not we should allow frustrations to boil over, whether or not we should tell people it is their problem and not ours.
From one generation to another, the Liberal tradition has been to stand up and fight for those people and find a solution. I personally find the expenditure plan lacking in energy and vision. Once again we see no particular plan of action for Winnipeg, or for any other big city in the country.
Canada is of a size where any government showing any sense of commitment can very quickly put together packages which do not overwhelm the treasury, to protect cities from the fundamental flaws we see in other countries. It is not good enough to sit back, watch TV and see another country or city crumble and say thank God it is not my city, province or country.
It is a chance to see what the worst signs and future can be, take the initiative and turn this around.
There are several things that can be done. I must say at the outset it is not a case of telling the government to come walking in with a big stick and big bucks and change things. No, no. The style of the 1990s must be that of partnership. There are organizations in the voluntary sector, well-meaning businesses, provincial governments and municipal governments. The field is filled with people with energy who want to make sure their cities work but they need one more actor at the table. They need a committed federal government.
What can the federal government bring to the table to help in the renewal of our cities that is not there now? First, the government can go back to CMHC and restore the long-standing commitment that we have to social housing and to assisting with low-rental housing across the country.
If we look at the dismal state of the housing market in this country and then look at the federal government expenditure plan, it is clear that there is a direct relationship. If the federal government, through CMHC, is not active in housing the market collapses in this country. If we want the strongest component for dealing with new Canadians who have put together non-profit
June 16, 1992

housing organizations, for seniors groups and for the Lions Clubs of this country, we need the federal government to be there to finance and show direction. But no, that opportunity has been passed over.
Second, if we look at the renewal of older neighbourhoods, one of the most successful programs that we have had, I would say since the early 1970s, has been the Residential Rehabilitation Assistance Program, RRAP. It successfully helped low income homeowners, and in some cases landlords who were dealing in low-rental areas, restore their property so they could stay there. They continue to stay there because of the activities. Think ahead seven or eight years if there were no repairs in the inner city. Then we can just begin to imagine the worst scenes we have seen on television being a backdrop to Canadian cities.
Third, there is youth employment. Why is it impossible for the federal government to properly fund Challenge '92? Why were so many students not given the opportunity to work? In the case of the constituency of Winnipeg North Centre as many as 9 out of 10 in the category of non-profit organizations were denied an opportunity to work this summer because of underfunding of a program. If you do not have a job, how can you have hope and how can you get educated?
Fourth, changes in the unemployment insurance program have pretty well prevented aboriginal youth and many women who have been out of the work force for some time from getting proper training. Without training it is impossible to take a step forward.
Fifth is safety in the cities. There are a number of regulations and laws within the Criminal Code that can be changed. There are a number of initiatives that can be taken by the Solicitor General's office. It could start up the race relations organization that has been long promised, and nothing has ever been done. Why has something not been done to help out with the fundamental question of safety on the streets?
This is not an issue from the right wing. This is not an issue on which it is possible to say: "Oh well, it is only the law and order people who are concerned about safety". The average Canadian family living in a big city is concerned with the safety of themselves, their children
Supply
and their parents. We, as a government, have an obligation to respond to this and come up with ways to design cities better, to make more functional laws and ensure that the support services are properly financed so that the basic question of personal safety is responded to more positively.
As for economic development, how can a city find its role in a new competitive world if the federal government, which is in charge of the trade arrangements and the international environment, does not take a concern with the individual cities of this country and in finding a role for the people living there in trading. What is the role of Winnipeg in the international economy? It has lost its role and it is having a difficult time understanding what it is to do. What is the expectation? How is it being helped by the federal government? There are 650,000 people living there and yet there is no plan for their economic functions.
On a much larger scale, the people of Montreal are facing the same crisis. The economic base of Montreal is very similar to that of Winnipeg. It relies upon the textile industry, the apparel industry, the construction industry, engineering and the transportation of commodities from the agricultural fields. They are all similar to components of the Winnipeg economy, and Montreal is suffering a similar collapse.
Does the government have in its expenditure plan that is under discussion today any particular points of reference to help the people of Montreal or Winnipeg? The answer is a resounding no.
If your national government decides that your problems are too small then how can you possibly begin to redevelop your own city? Where is the federal government when it comes to providing languages for new entrepreneurs in this country?
If we do want to develop trading partners in Asia, if we do want to develop partners in Eastern Europe, who has the language skills? Who has the documents in their language? Who has the ability to understand Canadian law and apply it to the international trade situation? Who is going to be supportive of the long trips over to these countries so that trade can begin?

Supply
It is not this government. That is what is sad. The expenditure plan has left out any reference to the tremendous problems facing Canadian cities. I use Winnipeg as an example but I could be talking to the House about Montreal, Toronto, or Edmonton. All these cities face a crisis, some of them somewhat different.
It is not for the federal government to come in and say: "We have the answer". However, it is up to the federal government to say: "We want to be a partner. Let us sit down at the table and let us go over a list of issues. You tell us what you need and we will help you form a better urban environment that will create jobs, create a strong economy, rebuild houses in neighbourhoods and get our cities going again".
The cities are the centre of economic energy and we must defend them.

Mr. Speaker, I was listening very intently with a great deal of interest to the excellent speech given by my colleague, the hon. member for Winnipeg North Centre.
I was struck by the common sense that he pronounced and the logic that he brought forward. At the basis of our Canadian society is the city itself. Therein we have the whole vehicle for our modem life in the urban context. If we allow our cities to become disorganized, to become debased, to decay and to become unruly then frankly we in this country have thrown away the very vehicle of our urban way of life.
I cannot help but think that this government is completely missing the boat when it comes to dealing with urban problems. He mentioned, and I think correctly, the violence in Los Angeles. It was a very tragic episode, not only in American history but in human history. That episode showed us that these problems have not been solved. The difficulty is ongoing, and it would seem that our governments are turning a blind eye to the problem or just do not know how to handle the situation.
From a judicial point of view, 8,000 people were arrested in the Los Angeles riots. It defies the imagination to understand how they are going to process these
8,000	people through an already crowded court system in the United States.
This is the sort of thinking that we must consider because what has happened in Los Angeles could very easily happen in Canada. We did have very unfortunate
riots in Toronto as a result of a shooting incident. They gave us a clear signal that Canada is not exempt from these problems. If we do not deal realistically and strategically with the problems that exist in our cities then we are going to be faced with ever-increasing violence and disruption.
As the hon. member has mentioned, we must deal with the questions of housing and employment but we also have to work together at the three levels of government.
The Minister of Justice stated that she is promoting meetings and dialogue with the mayors of the major cities in Canada. Hopefully in a year's time we will have a meeting of the three levels of government, but this does not seem to me to be the response that is urgently required and that Canadians want.
The government must get in better contact with not only the problems that exist in our cities but also with the difficulties that it seems to be having in entering into a dialogue with supposedly friendly provinces and municipalities.
The situation goes much further than just the cities themselves. It goes to the thinking that seems to permeate our society today. There is a survival of the fittest attitude. Unfortunately this attitude is manifesting itself in very derogatory ways. For instance we do not seem to be doing what we should be doing for single parents and their children, ex-wives who have been separated or divorced from their husbands and are finding themselves incapable of meeting the expenses of raising their children let alone looking after their own needs.
We have a tax system that allows the ex-husband to deduct his payments to the ex-wife and children but the wife who receives the payments must pay taxes on what she receives.
We have heard that the courts and other authorities tell us that when the wives and children do get the money, it is less than half of what they need to raise the children. We are told that 12 per cent of the ex-husbands are living below the poverty line but 66 per cent of the ex-wives and families are living in poverty, even if they are receiving payments. If they do not receive the payment, that poverty level figure is increased to 75 per cent.
June 16, 1992	COMMONS
There must be more recognition of what needs to be done and how it is going to be done. If not then we are saying that our federal system stymies the justice and the equity that we all expect to have in this country. However, the government is not only turning away and not recognizing the problems that exist but it is also wilfully abandoning the programs that had meant so much in cementing our society, bringing people together, and giving people hope.
I just want to deal with two programs as they refer to the justice system. The first is the Court Challenges Program. We have talked to the government. We have asked questions in the House. We have asked questions in committee as to why the government would possibly do away with the Court Challenges Program. It is incredible to think that this program has been jettisoned by the government.
It is a program that cost $2.4 million. Certainly $2.4 million is a considerable sum of money, but we should consider that this program allowed disadvantaged and poor people to be able to take their perceived injustices and questions to court. Not everybody was given financing, but if it was determined that their case was something that needed to be brought forward and needed to be determined, viewed and questioned then the organizing group gave them funding of up to a maximum of $35,000 toward their legal fees.
This has been of immeasurable help to us. Not only has it helped disadvantaged people, visible minorities, single mothers, and aboriginal people but it has brought forward a good body of law. It helped us to enrich the body of law that we so proudly speak about in this country.
We have had court decisions that have resulted from the Court Challenges Program such as the Butler case, in which it was determined by a vote of nine to nothing that the obscenity rules in this country were directly related to violence against women and violence against the family. This now allows us to proceed, I would have hoped faster than we have, with tougher pornography laws, in particular, so that we can protect our children from this degrading and abusive form of material.
Also, we are doing away with our Law Reform Commission which has been the genesis of a great deal of our

Supply
legal thinking. We have talked about the various bills in this House. We have discussed cases where in at least 44 recent Supreme Court decisions the Law Reform Commission was cited as being the origin of the particular legal thinking.
We now have Bill C-46 before the House, the contraventions bill. In 1976, it was the Law Reform Commission that requested this. The government first brought it forward in 1986 and finally we have the legislation that we have today.
It seems the government is determined to do it, but if we do away with our Law Reform Commission then Canada will be one of three Commonwealth countries without a law reform commission. We will be joining Zimbabwe and Bangladesh as the only three Commonwealth countries without a law reform commission.
Quebec is now in the process of setting up a law reform commission. This will mean that all provinces in Canada have a law reform commission, but the federal government does not. It is a travesty in a federal system that we would abandon this role and not consider our law more important than we have.
I think I have 20 minutes, Mr. Speaker.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I want to be sure because we have a motion that members of your party will split the time for their speeches.

My colleague is in committee and cannot leave, unfortunately.
There is a certain fibre, a certain cement that we have had in Canada. We have been able to relate one to the other, we have been able to care for one another, we have been conscious of the needs of one another. It seems that these programs and these concerns are dissipating. It is mainly because the government is choosing not to keep those programs going.
In a lot of cases the government has set up or initiated good programs, such as the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency, employment programs and various labour initiatives. It then has proceeded to reduce the funding for those programs which is counterproductive. This is not the way to proceed.

June 16, 1992
Supply
I also want to give a great deal of credit to the hon. member for South West Nova and to compliment her on the comments she made concerning the Cornwallis base. It is a tremendously important facility in Nova Scotia and Atlantic Canada.
When we see new institutions being funded and reorganization in the Armed Forces taking place when we have this excellent facility in Nova Scotia, the thought, even the very germ of an idea that we would let this facility go is absolutely galling and ridiculous. It is a marvellous facility not only in the technological expertise that exists there but also in the infrastructure which is so costly today. It has an excellent infrastructure and is in a marvellous location with very competent personnel. The thought that we would let this go is unthinkable. I certainly hope the government will listen to the words and reasons put forward by the hon. member for South West Nova. It is well worth listening to. It is a benefit to her constituents and to the country as a whole.
Frankly, the situation in Atlantic Canada is very bad at the present time. I think the government is trying not to notice this. How government members can possibly not notice it, how they can possibly come into the House and not be completely and utterly embarrassed by their treatment of Atlantic Canada is very perplexing to me.
In my constituency on Cape Breton Island we have a devastating economic problem. The meaningful programs we expect from government are not forthcoming. There does not seem to be a recognition of what is going on in Atlantic Canada and certainly on Cape Breton Island.
The community has no understanding whatsoever as to why the federal government has abandoned its role in Atlantic Canada.
We have the situation in the fisheries. We have asked the government time after time to please tell us what will be done as compensation for those who are going to be losing their livelihood.
In Newfoundland there are thousands of communities depending exclusively on the fishery. On Cape Breton Island there are communities which are completely
dependent on the fishery. These communities will suffer irreparable harm if the fishery is closed. What is the government doing? It is causing tremendous anguish.
In Nova Scotia and Cape Breton we had an excellent tourist industry. It has been hurt by the GST and by higher taxes on gasoline. We depend mainly on Americans visiting our region and frankly, the GST and the gasoline tax are disincentives to come to our region.
It may be said that applications to obtain a GST rebate can be made. People just do not go through that process. They are not prepared to go through that hassle. They will stay at home. They will go as far as Maine, Vermont or New Hampshire and decide that is as far as they will go. We will lose the assistance we could have had from their visits.
This is so fundamental. It seems that everything in Atlantic Canada right now is tainted as far as the economy is concerned. Something has happened pretty well on all fronts to cause questions in every industry and every form of livelihood. This is a mystery to us all as to how this could have been allowed to happen to the extent that it has.
This is a great country, even though we have our economic difficulties at the present time. There seems to be different levels of Canadians. There is a gulf between the more prosperous regions of the country and the less prosperous, between the rich and the poor, and that gulf seems to be widening. This was not the way it was supposed to be. This was not Canada as most of us thought of it. This was not the idea that we ever imagined would be of such prominence in our country as it is today.
