This cannot really be allowed to continue because if it is we are going to ruin the spirit of the country as we know it.
Certainly in Atlantic Canada there is the feeling because the four provinces together only have a total of 32 seats that politically, government believes Atlantic Canada is expendable. The government asks: "Why worry about the fishery? Why worry about the tourist industry? Why worry about agriculture in Atlantic Canada? Why worry about the forest industry? Why worry about the communities that are suffering such difficulty? Because we can win an election and not have to worry about Atlantic Canada".
June 16, 1992

That thinking is diabolical. I want this government to reassess its actions. I want this government to reassess the needs that it is giving priority.
I want this government to realize that the four provinces of Atlantic Canada are very much in need of their federal government. The federal government cannot just say that at the very best, it is going to allow the concerns of Atlantic Canada to wait for another day when there are not so many other things on its plate. These people are good Canadians and they need the support of their government. They are asking for the support of their government and they are not getting it.
I want this government to reappraise its priorities. I want this government to be mindful there are Canadians in Atlantic Canada needing its help. I would suggest right now that there be plans and there be analyses of the economic situation and that the proper regional development framework and assistance in the short term be put in place.
What has happened is a tragedy and if something is not done very soon, the damage will be irreparable. These people who have depended on their government will find their government not anxious and in fact not even willing to help them when they need that government assistance so badly.

Mr. Speaker, I found the intervention by the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys quite interesting. I was intrigued by his having mentioned early in his discourse the benefits provided to the visible minority community by the Court Challenges Program.
I wonder if he realizes that in fact the Court Challenges Program was never used to bring a single case to the Supreme Court of Canada. At the time the government decided to terminate the program there was an attempt to organize young lawyers within the black community to begin to initiate some cases. In fact, the Court Challenges Program was about to be used for the first time by visible minorities. I would like to hear what he thinks about that.
How does the hon. member relate that in the present social context to the fact that at the same time, the Law Reform Commission had prepared a preliminary report examining the issue of jury selection as it related to what had been suspected in Ontario to be an exclusion of visible minorities from juries? It was an initiative taken
Supply
by Ontario to pursue that issue. Can that be seen to have a relationship to the government's decision to delay the implementation of legislation on the Race Relations Institute?
In short, there are a number of elements in the decision of the government to terminate programs or commissions that have impacted seriously on the ability of visible minorities to exercise their right to be a part of the process. This is at the very time when the issue of racial discrimination has become critical in many parts of this country.
Is all of this in some way connected to the introduction of sharp changes in the refugee determination system? This is at a time when the Reform Party is raising xenophobic questions with respect to government policy on immigration. Are we not finding a kind of xenophobic government in terms of the legislation that it is passing in response to the Reform Party and in disregard to the concerns of a considerable sector of the community?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the hon. member for his questions and his comments. What he says is correct.
While the Court Challenges Program has not brought a case to the Supreme Court involving visible minorities, the matter had been under consideration and there was an attempt to correct that. It was unfortunate that the visible minorities did not get more support from the Court Challenges Program.
I think it is unfortunate too that the Court Challenges Program has been cancelled. The deficiencies of the program did not get a chance to be corrected. I feel that it could have played a very important part for visible minorities. They never really had the full benefit of it. I think that is extremely wrong, particularly when we are talking now about amending our Constitution and amending the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
The government is in fact saying: "We don't need the Court Challenges Program any more", and at the same time considering these amendments. We are going to have to look at these amendments in light of their relationship to our legal system. The effect on visible minorities, aboriginal people and other groups is going to be very important. At this particular time when we need it so badly, the government is withdrawing it.

June 16, 1992
Supply
The member also talks about the Law Reform Commission and the jury selection process. He is right on that as well. This is something that was being looked at. Hopefully we were going to have a meaningful commentary on that.
We also had a very good report in process on the law and multiculturalism, an excellent program that dealt with the law relating to visible minorities and the various groups in our communities and exactly trying to relate one to the other. The actual fundamental preparation for it had been completed. In fact, there was a group of consultants from the various multicultural communities who were to meet with the government to discuss the report four days after the budget was presented.
The budget was presented cancelling the Law Reform Commission, the meeting was cancelled. These meetings have never been rescheduled. To the knowledge of the multicultural community, they do not know where the reports sits. They do not know if these meetings will ever take place. In fact, they are now of the mind that they will never see this report, that this report will never be made public. This is an unmitigated tragedy when we consider how much has gone into it and how much we need this report.
That is just the callous thinking and the disregard that exists.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to my hon. colleague and I thank him for his support for Cornwallis. I could not help but think that the question put prior to me was an appropriate one and leans toward the question that I would like to ask the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys.
The member mentioned ACOA, the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency. It has not proved to be very effective. In this government's implementation of ACOA, it has not proved to be an effective use of creating jobs or bringing new ideas into my area. I think I speak not only for my area but for the surrounding communities south of Halifax. We have seen it play a role in tourism, in building hotels and things like that.
Has the member experienced the same thing and does he have any ideas? I do. I have a couple of suggestions. I wonder if the member would like to comment on where ACOA has gone wrong under this government in terms
of delivering $2 billion. I think most of my constituents would like to see where the $2 billion is going.

Mr. Speaker, I would say to the hon. member for South West Nova that we would all like to know where the $2 billion went. It is probably the biggest mystery of all when we are talking about ACOA.
The concept of ACOA on paper initially was not a bad concept. What happened was that political patronage became the dominant consideration in ACOA. Moneys were given depending upon who you were and what constituency you lived in and what you had in your wherewithal to be able to do for the government at a later date.
That is crass. It was the number one criteria for ACOA.
By Cape Breton standards, we received considerable funding for large industries that were organized and applied for by people outside of the jurisdiction. They were given a lot of money. They could not turn the money down. We do not know what relationship they had with anybody in the government or the Public Service, so I cannot comment specifically.
They came in. They set up the businesses. They employed people who wanted jobs badly. The local people worked very hard only to find that when the funding was used up and the tax credit was gone, the job training grants were used up, all of a sudden the doors were closed in the industries.
These people were not only without a job once again, but actually had their hopes dashed because they thought that finally they were going to have something worth while and they were going to have a future. They were going to be able to look after their families and make a home for themselves in Cape Breton without having to worry about where the next pay cheque was going to come from.
This is not the situation now. We find ourselves back to square one. What we need to do is foster the local entrepreneurs who have a stake in the community and who have shown that they want to live in the community and to help them, not because of what political party they support or what they can do but on the basis of their ideas and what they want to do for the community.
June 16, 1992

That is going to have to be a fundamental consideration.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to speak to the government's Main Estimates for the current year.
However, I find it very difficult to understand why a number of opposition members have been telling us since this morning that the government does not spend enough. They complained that the government withdrew from certain programs and that it cut spending. We tabled Main Estimates totalling $160 billion for the year
1992-93. This does not include the interest charges on the debt we inherited, an irresponsible debt that goes back to the seventies and the beginning of the eighties, a $200 billion debt that causes all kinds of problems because of the interest which accumulates each year. I wonder how anyone could claim today that the government is not spending enough money when we realize that we have a budget of around $120 billion, that the public complains it is being overtaxed and we are being asked to increase spending in practically all the government's current programs. We are even being asked to introduce new programs. I realize there is significant need, but people should also realize that if we want to control taxes, if we want to reduce taxes, we will have to stop increasing program spending, or at least cut certain programs and focus on the priorities.
I think it would be interesting to consider how the tax money the government will collect this year to provide services to Canadians will be spent.
I just mentioned that first of all we have an unfortunate situation where a significant share of the government's tax revenue will go to paying the interest on our debt. The debt keeps increasing annually because we do not have the money to pay the interest, let alone the principal. This means that 25 cents out of every dollar spent in 1992-93 will be applied to debt charges.
There are members who wonder why the government keeps blaming the previous government for the deficit. They say it has now been seven or eight years and we should be able to find something else to talk about and come up with other reasons.
Supply
Unfortunately, as we have been repeating for six, seven or eight years, this debt got out of control and is causing problems now and will continue to do so for generations. The government became so ambitious that its revenues no longer covered its expenditures. It had to borrow to pay for programs it was making available to Canadians and which it really could not afford.
The fact is that more than 50 per cent of budgetary expenditures consist of amounts paid to individuals through our programs and through agencies and provincial and territorial governments. People still complain in this House about cutbacks in transfer payments to governments and individuals. That is entirely false. These expenditures have increased from year to year. I mentioned earlier that if we go back to the 1984 budget, this was a $70 million budget. Of course, the government was running an operating deficit of $16 billion that year, which meant its budget was actually $86 billion.
The fact remains that today, planned budget spending totals about $120 billion, which means that transfers to the provinces, instead of going down, have increased on an annual basis. Of course we had to limit those increases in recent years, in this budget as well, but there again, instead of cutting spending on transfer payments, the government is doing everything it can, within the fiscal room it has to manoeuvre, to keep upgrading these transfers and respond to the public's expectations as much as possible.
Eight per cent of this budget will be spent on defence. We have taken some very substantial measures to control defence spending, and new guidelines have been issued to deal with our new obligations to replace obsolete military equipment. We had to cut defence personnel to be able to modernize our fleet. However, 8 per cent of the budget will still be spent on defence.
As for Crown corporations, 3 per cent of the budget will cover that item, while 11 per cent is allocated to services other than defence, offered directly to Canadians by the federal government. These services are part of the cost of government operations. There are officials and people who provide those services, and these people have to be paid. This includes salaries and wages. It includes accommodation. It also includes equipment for inspecting food and drugs, if we want to protect the

Supply
public and ensure our food is safe to eat. Of course it takes money to have this kind of control.
We have to control enforcement of environmental regulations. I think that investing in the environment is becoming increasingly critical. I think the public expects its leaders to take certain steps and invest in correcting the problems that have developed over the years. The opposition is asking the government to act, but I think it will realize how aware we are of the country's needs. We know a lot more money will be spent on dealing with environmental problems.
We also know how important air safety control is. This is part of the budget for services like aircraft safety and scientific research. We know that it is important to invest in research if we want to meet the challenges of the years ahead. Surveys and mapping are all services in which the government must invest and of course they are in the budget.
The budget also includes fields like health and safety. I see the Minister of Health here and we know very well that we must invest large amounts year after year for better health services and in research for the benefit of Canadians. Canada is a privileged country in this field.
Of course it is not perfect, but we must continue. We will find in the budget the money needed to correct the problems we have identified.
I just spoke about food. Food quality in Canada is the envy of the world, but we must keep track of it, monitor and control it. There are also the environment, medicine and roads. A country as large as Canada must invest heavily in its road system. As well, there are the seaway, airways, airports, ships and harbours. That is all part of our budget.
We often forget all that. We often take all the services we enjoy for granted, but of course they cost something and that is found in the budget. This budget also includes the protection of other consumer interests, like inspections and enforcing regulations on such things as weights and measures, communications and financial institutions.
Social programs and programs for native people are also found in our budget. Most Canadian families receive some income support. We know how important our old
age pensions are to give our seniors a decent life. In addition, unemployment insurance is a huge cost in a difficult period when Canada must restructure its economy and face new challenges.
A major investment must be made in unemployment insurance benefits, because obviously in a time of such great change, Canadians are hit and they must be protected until the situation returns to normal. We can talk about family allowances. We know how important it is to help our Canadian families.
For that reason this budget gives more to deal with those needs, even though the government has very little room to move. As for competitiveness, I said that we are now going through extraordinary changes with the opening of markets; we talk about globalization of trade and we must face tremendous competition. It will not decrease but become more intense. Therefore we must invest and that is what we do in this budget.
We are investing large amounts in science, technology and the infrastructure we will need to face all those problems. We must also protect people and property. We are involved in security, policing, the courts, prisons and social reintegration of offenders. Again, we know that we are going through a difficult period and need more and more good security services in this country.
We have passed legislation on the security of individuals, of Canadians.
Structures and infrastructures must be provided to ensure public safety and deal with people who have had a brush with the law for one reason or another. Money must be spent for their rehabilitation. We cannot neglect them and let them turn into bad citizens. We have to see to it that they are rehabilitated as quickly as possible and, of course, that costs money.
As far as border protection is concerned, we know full well that to preserve its sovereignty, Canada has to protect its borders. A lot of money had to go that way. Canada is a three-ocean country and, as such, has borders, the traffic through which needs to be monitored. In order to be able to afford providing such services to the public, naturally money must be raised. Unfortunately, this means levying taxes. To do so, we
June 16, 1992

need personnel and materials. Administering all that costs quite a bit of money.
Regarding the Immigration Act, again, we are a nation of immigrants in Canada. But this does not mean that immigration just happens. Controls are required as well as all kinds of expenditures that we have to take into account in our budget.
On the revenue side, there are the proceeds of the Customs Act, but then again, money has to be spent in order to collect custom and excise duties.
In a rich, prosperous country such as ours, in spite of the indebtedness I talked about earlier, compared to other countries, there is no doubt that we are privileged. It is our duty as elected members of Parliament to provide cultural and recreation services to our people, and a lot is invested in that. I think that a proud country like Canada must provide cultural services to promote culture throughout the country.
There is also the representation and protection of Canadian interests abroad. We do have to be represented abroad, world-wide, and that entails considerable expenses.
Add to that foreign aid. Considering how privileged we are as a nation, as I pointed out earlier, compared to other, poorer nations, these do need assistance of course. I believe Canada cannot afford not to provide assistance to countries where people die from hunger, which is not the case in Canada. I think it is the thing to do to provide assistance to bring hope to these countries and help them achieve some level of prosperity.
Finally, there are the parliamentary institutions, activities that all members of this House certainly consider as essential to maintain our democratic system. There is more. But I think you get a pretty good idea of how where the money goes, of how the taxpayers money is spent. .
I would like to remind hon. members of one thing, especially those opposite, and I will close off on this. I have been sitting in this House for four years now and I would like the opposition members who, day in day out, criticize government for their lack of consideration for the Canadian citizens, for their lack of consideration in programs offered to provide security and an adequate quality of life, to keep one thing in mind. By the way, a recent United Nations study carried out throughout the
Supply
world concluded that Canada was the country where citizens were afforded the best quality of life. Nevertheless, I believe that a lot needs to be done. Many Canadians are in need and need assistance, but let us not forget that there is a limit to how much taxpayers can pay. Canadians are already overtaxed. We cannot afford to increase our expenses without cutting somewhere else because we cannot go over the $160 billion planned for this year. We cannot even think of doubling this amount. Somebody would have to pay for it eventually.
I would therefore ask the members in the opposition to tone down their criticism and stop blaming the government for the shortfalls of just about every single one of its programs. There is a price to pay. In fact we have already reached the limit and I think that the recent budget is reasonable and that it will enable us to meet our obligations. We must of course take care of those people who require government assistance, but it is about time that most people who can provide for themselves do so without counting on the government, especially as regards unemployment insurance and welfare for which we provide transfer payments. At this point in time, we must focus our efforts on those members of our society who are in the greatest need of help. Mr. Speaker, all this is to say that this budget is extremely important and that it will allow a decent living for all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I want to say to my friend that I listened attentively to his remarks and there were many things he said with which I agree.
I especially want to focus on that part of his speech near the end where he said that we must look after those who are in most need. It is important to explain to the people of Canada where we as Liberals have a different point of view from the government.
The people who are most in need right now in this country are those people who are out of work. We are talking of more than two million people.
It seems to me that if we are already spending about $35 billion in unemployment insurance and welfare, if we were to maybe add another $5 billion or $6 billion to that amount, we could probably get those people into the work force. Then we would have a productive labour force and it would not be the same sort of drain on the

June 16, 1992
Supply
treasury. We would be creating an asset for that work, whereas right now these disbursements on welfare and unemployment insurance, not to mention the fact there is a lack of productivity, are a real affront to a person's dignity.
The government is constantly telling Canadians that we cannot do this because of the deficit and the debt of the nation. The member said we are paying about 25 cents on the dollar in interest payments. I personally do not think that is such a big deal.
In other words, if someone has a mortgage of $100,000 on their house and they make around $50,000 or $60,000 a year, they are paying 25 per cent or 26 per cent in interest rates and they manage to get by.
My question for the member is does he not think that Canadians without a tax increase could handle another $5 billion or $6 billion for the mortgage of this country if it meant we could put those two million people back to work?

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the hon. member for his question. He says that if we got another five or six billion dollars into debt, we could eliminate unemployment in this country.
Without wishing to be overly partisan, I would say that if we realize the extent of our current debt-
It's not too much.

It may not be too much, but we must not forget that the $400 million worth of debt some people seem to take for granted costs us 25 cents out of every dollar we collect to provide services for Canadians.
In fact, it costs us about $40 billion annually. When you talk about five or six billion, my answer is that if you had planned things differently 20 years ago, with the same tax revenue we would have had $40 billion to distribute in the form of services to Canadians.
The honourable member says that with five or six billion more, we could eliminate unemployment. Sure,
there would be no more unemployed left in this country and we could even offer them bonuses.
Experience has shown that this kind of investment, and I am referring to borrowing to inject money into the economy, does nothing to deal with the problem. If that were the case, there would be no unemployment today. However, it is not the answer, and that is not how we will create jobs.
It is not the answer, because what is important today is training. The problem is not only the debt we have been handed down over the years but the fact that we have failed to train people for the jobs available today and the jobs available in the future. What we have to do now should have been done 20 years ago: train people so they will be able to work.
The jobs are there. In Canada, between 500,000 and
600,000	jobs would be available if we had the right people to fill them. However, people are not trained for these jobs. It would be wonderful if we had a magic formula that would deal with the problem overnight, but there is no miracle solution. We have to do what should have been done long ago, which is train people and prepare them for the jobs of tomorrow, and that is how we will become a prosperous country.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I am sorry to interrupt the hon. member, but other members have a few questions.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to the speech by the hon. member for Joliette, who said several times that the United Nations had referred to Canada as the country with the best quality of life in the world. I also heard this on television, and I heard about the UN criteria for this kind of statement.
However, the UN overlooked a very important item. It forgot to say that Canada has been living on credit for the past 30 years. It also forgot to say what Canada would be like during the next five years. I predict that five years from now, Canada will be almost bankrupt. People will not say so, because they assume a country cannot go bankrupt, so let us say Canada will be getting increasingly poorer. In fact, we realize we are getting poorer every day.
June 16, 1992

Unemployment and the debt are out of control because we have 11 political powers in this country that are constantly bickering and cannot reach any kind of consensus, which means that all this is costing us a lot of money. A sovereign Quebec and a sovereign Canada with a dignified form of association would save us between three and five billion dollars, strictly in operating costs. Imagine how efficient we would be. We might save between 15 and 20 billion dollars. That is how we can stop Canada from going bankrupt.
If you want your beautiful Canada to go bankrupt, make a sovereign Canada with a sovereign Quebec, and an association between the two, and in this way we could have effective administration and together keep Canada from going bankrupt.
Perhaps we should invite the UN and give it some real criteria by which to judge what is good or bad for Canada.
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the hon. member, the sovereignist from Longueuil.
The sovereign.

Indeed, the sovereign of Longueuil. I want to thank the hon. member for his comments. He predicts that the future will not be rosy. He is a pessimist. I say everything will be alright, and I know it will be. Granted, as Canadians-all the provinces made the same mistake-we live beyond our means. We took advantage of our natural resources, but now we realize we have to change. We have to roll up our sleeves and adjust to a modem world, and then we will be on the road to prosperity.
When the hon. member says: "We are going to separate from Canada and we are all going to save money", I find that hard to believe. I am not so sure that will happen.
Mr. Parizeau in Quebec City says: "If we separate, we will reduce government spending. It will cost less in administration costs". When public servants in Hull started asking questions about their future-
That's Rocheleau's riding.

It is in the riding of Hull. Mr. Parizeau told them: "Don't worry, you won't lose your jobs. We are going to keep you all". Someone will have to explain how we can cut spending if we keep spending the same amount of money and maintain the same number of employees and provide the same services. Someone will
Supply
have to explain why this is such an ideal solution. Mr. Speaker, we will continue this some other time. I thank you very much.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Dura lex, sed lex, as they used to say.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise this evening to join in this debate on the Main Estimates.
I do so in the context of just having come back from the earth summit. It was a very intense experience, where the heads of state of 170 countries were united for three days by a lack of vision, a lack of urgency, and a seeming commitment to put national interests ahead of overwhelming global concerns.
I think they are all deserving of the condemnation of their citizens.
That having been said, in the Main Estimates we are talking about priorities of government. It is very clear coming out of the earth summit in Rio that what is required is a fundamental rethinking about what is important. I have been listening to the debate this afternoon and we are talking about the debt problem and so on, so there are political choices that have to be made.
I would like to inject a little sense of urgency this afternoon. Maurice Strong has a quote that is worthy of repetition: "We can be intellectually pessimistic, but we must be operationally optimistic". That is going to be my theme today. I figure I can be operationally optimistic by exposing some of the very skewed priorities of this government. It seems to be able to find money for the weirdest schemes and yet the money that is used to make a fundamental change that is so urgent in our world seems to be beyond it.
These are political choices made by this government and it is going to be responsible for having made them. I give the House one example. Dr. Nafis Sadik, the head of the UN Population Fund, confronted the representatives from those 170 countries with the need to increase social spending as a means of curbing over-population. Quite frankly, the population of the globe is growing so quickly that we are going to be losing space for future generations. It is not sustainable population growth. What does this government do on population?

June 16, 1992
Supply
In the last five years, it has decreased funding for planned parenthood. In 1984-85, it decreased it by 15.6 per cent, in 1985-86, by 12.5 per cent and in 1986-87, by 20 per cent. This shows the kind of wrong thinking this government has in its caucus. On the one hand, it wants to introduce abortion legislation and on the other hand it takes away funding for planned parenthood, to give women the wherewithal to find out about how to prevent unwanted pregnancies. This is an investment in our society that this government has chosen not to make.
It is an interesting statistic, further on the population issue, that the way to address overpopulation is to increase the access to education for women. It is an interesting statistic that for a woman who has not completed secondary education, the average number of children she will have is seven. If a woman has secondary education, that number drops to three which is still not a sustainable number but four less than seven. An investment in education for women is one thing this government should be doing, making education an attractive choice that young women could make.
The other way where the population can be decreased is if women have more participation in political decisionmaking. It is interesting and I think quite instructive that the Prime Minister remarked only a few weeks ago that Canada's international reputation depends on what his government does at home. I agree with that. It is interesting that at Rio there was not one government woman member on the delegation. This, in spite of the fact that the ministers both for external relations and for external affairs are both women.
Who does the government choose to send down to represent Canada's interests? Quite appropriately, the Minister for the Environment who did do a good job representing Canada. The other minister was the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans. This was not a conference about fish, this was a conference about the future of the planet. Women make up more than 50 per cent of the human population on this planet. But no, the government does not send down a woman minister to represent it, it sent down another man to talk about fish. That is very instructive and it goes back to what I said earlier about governments acting out of national self-interest rather than very critical global concerns. I would like
now to turn closer to home and talk about those other choices that this government has made because of course when you are government you have to make the tough choices. It is bizarre at best.
For example, the announcement when I was in Rio. I was incredulous to hear that there was a proposal to spend $4.3 billion for the world's most expensive high-tech helicopters to combat the Soviet threat. Has the government not been reading the papers lately? There is no longer a Soviet threat. Why does it not use the $4.3 billion to buy the whole Soviet submarine fleet? It seems that would make about as much sense.
The government says that those helicopters are going to be used for search and rescue. As a representative of a coastal community where some of those helicopters would be based, I should be in favour of this. I am in favour of the remotoring of those helicopters. I am in favour of giving the adequate resources for those helicopter pilots to do the job that they have to do. They do a good job with poor equipment in very unruly weather on the west coast of British Columbia.
However, when you put $4.3 billion up against $145 million in debt forgiveness that the Prime Minister announced last week, one wonders about the political priorities of this government. One wonders if the world has gone mad when we see that this is the way the government is behaving.
Put it also up against the $1.3 billion of federal funds per year for national municipal infrastructure where
63,000	jobs could be created. If we are going to spend $4.3 billion, let me make the shopping list for a change. Give me an opportunity. I could find a way to spend $4.3 billion which I think would be a more fundamental way of making those changes that are so necessary if this planet is going to survive.
The $40 million on proposed cuts including feasibility studies, consultant fees and designs for the purchase of extensive high-tech helicopters is just a ridiculous proposal for expenditure. Put that against the promise of this government in 1984 and again in 1988 for a national child care program. We are hearing repeated horrifying incidents of child abuse in Canada. Yet this government
June 16, 1992

does not seem to see the linkage, that a national child care program would go a long way in addressing that.
The government is not giving it because the members of its caucus are in favour of keeping women in the kitchen and keeping a more traditional family. Those years have passed. Women are not in the home in the kitchen anymore. They are out supporting their families. The economy demands that they do that.
The people who are suffering are the children who do not have adequate child care. They are forced to be latchkey kids where they come home on their own after school or they have sort of take-a-chance kind of baby-sitting services where there are no standards. We need a publicly funded national child care program. If we really believe in supporting the family then we have to be able to give the resources to the people of Canada so the children have support.
Then there is the expenditure, and this is another whacko idea, of $1 billion on low-level defence systems. Who are we being defended from? We are talking billions of dollars.
I will go back to the millions, what the government did not fund. It cut $200 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy, something that I know every single riding in Canada benefits from. Over the last two years of job training, a number of people have been employed, have been retrained and have been sent out into the work force.
What does this government do? It cuts $200 million from it.
Another example. The Conservatives cut three federal agencies which provided expert advice to the government; the Law Reform Commission, the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada, costing $19 million. That was 185 lost jobs. The government also eliminated support for the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
This is a time when the whole definition of what constitutes security is being redefined and the government eliminates funding for it. But it managed to find money, $46.7 million including a $13.7 million cost overrun on the Canadian pavilion at the World Exposition in Seville, Spain. Just so that viewers will know, that pavilion will be dismantled after Expo.
Supply
Is that an investment? It is no wonder that the Canadian taxpayers feel overburdened when they can see the kind of absolutely whacko ideas this government chooses to spend our money on.
The government has also capped the Canada Assistance Plan funding to Ontario, B.C. and Alberta. For B.C. alone, that means a loss of $166 million in 1991-92. But $50 million was found to support Canada 125 Corporation, a private non-profit corporation to promote Canada's birthday. Well, I can buy my own candles. I can bring my own hooter and wish Canada a happy birthday, and it is not going to cost $50 million.
The government has terminated the co-op housing program, a cut of $25 million. As the representative of one of the fastest growing ridings in Canada and also one of the most expensive ridings in Canada in which to live, this is a scandal that the co-op housing program has been eliminated. It is not only the wealthy who live in Saanich-Gulf Islands. It is those young families that are scraping along trying to find a way to buy a home. Co-op housing is often used as a start. But this government has chosen to terminate the co-op housing program, a $25 million cut. There was about $19 million found by the department of the Minister for International Trade for the propaganda and promotion of the Conservative "prosperity agenda". I put that in quotes because prosperity for whom, I ask?
Then there was the $14 million to sell the GST that nobody wanted. Believe me, that sales job was a big failure. There is still a lot of anger about the GST. On the other hand, the government has cut the Court Challenges Program in the 1992 budget, $2.7 million a year, that was allowing equality seeking groups and individuals access to courts to enforce their rights.
One wonders where the grand plan is when you see these comparisons. What is the priority of this government? It is more than just a coincidence that it is the social programs that are getting the short end of the stick while the flimflam and public relations it always seems to find the dollars for.
There was $800,000 to $1 million spent on new cars for cabinet ministers and senior mandarins over the last year, replacing vehicles still in top condition but not quite so bright and shiny. But there was also $3.4 million in cuts for funding for the aboriginal communications program.

Supply
In conclusion, this demonstrates that this government is devoid of vision, devoid of that sense of urgency I talked about that is necessary if we are going to survive into the 21st century. Maurice Strong was right that we can be intellectually pessimistic. We must be operationally optimistic. By speaking today in the House, I wish to expose the vacuous nature of this government's planning. It feels that by putting a fresh coat of paint on or a new ad that it can solve a lot of problems. This is not so. You have to get down and roll up your sleeves and work from the ground up by funding child care centres, funding family planning centres, educating women, putting more money into investments for education and technology and investing in the future of our country.
We have that vision and I hope when the election is called that people will see the vacuity of this government's agenda and choose a New Democrat government.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands. I must say that over all I agreed with many of her concerns about the government.
As members know, I do not share the ideology of this Prime Minister on the way this country should be governed. I have a different view than he does on free trade. I do not believe in this decentralist approach that is going on with the Constitution. However, I have to say to the member that I have a totally different view of the Prime Minister's actions in Rio last weekend.
I felt that the Prime Minister of Canada did a good job in Rio. I know it may sound strange coming from a Liberal to say that this Conservative Prime Minister did a good job on the environment, but I will state why I think he did do a good job. I thought that he stole the show when it came to the environment. In other words, this $140 million debt that we probably never would have had returned to us anyway, he managed to write off and create the perception that Canada was throwing in its oar, or to quote Maurice Strong: "He was operationally optimistic. He committed a further $20 million". I had some constituents on Saturday morning when I went to the Albion restaurant on Queen Street saying: "There he goes again, writing off another $140 million on the environment. What is he doing?"
As I said to the people in the restaurant on Saturday morning: "That is the cheapest $140 million Canadians
ever spent, not to mention the environmental cause. Just think of the doors that will open for all of our environmental consultations, our environmental technologies and all of these things that are manufactured in Canada". Quite frankly, I think this was probably one of the best things this Prime Minister has done since he has come to this office.
My question to the member is: Because this person is of a different stripe, can he not do anything in terms of contributing to the dynamic of this country? In this case I personally would have liked to have seen him do more in terms of his commitment to the environment. It would not have bothered me if he had written off $250 million because, as many of us have said in this House, if we cannot save the planet, what good is the debt owing to us anyway?
If we are going to win credibility on this issue, I do not think that the New Democrats or the Liberals are the only ones who are concerned or committed to saving the planet. In this case the Prime Minister opened doors for us around the world where now if we just put our Canadian business card out there, I will bet we are going to get preferential treatment for environmental technology and environmental service for many, many years to come. I think that is what Maurice Strong meant when he talked about operational optimism.

The hon. member's question and his comments preceding it demonstrate that national selfinterest also extends to the Liberal party and not just to the Conservative Party.
In my comments I did compliment the Minister of the Environment for his performance in Rio. That compliment did not extend to the Prime Minister.
The 16 negotiators that Canada had there did an exemplary job. They did a stalwart job representing Canada. They are public servants of the highest calibre.
However there were only 16 of them doing that work and they had to work around the clock to be able to do their work. Compare that to the 22 from the communications unit whose job was to sell the story back in Canada. This demonstrates the real priorities of this government. It is willing to put more into flimflam than it is into substance.
June 16, 1992

The member's reaction shows that it is working with the Liberals, and that is why my operational optimism is to expose it.
As for the international debt issue, the $145 million write-off, we were never going to paid back that money anyway. Canadian taxpayers are paying it anyway, through bank rates, through interest rates. It is the bankers who are benefiting. The bankers are benefiting not Canadians.
The writing off of that debt is only one part of the solution to this problem. We have to realize that if there are going to be real changes it is going to have to be more than a $145 million write-off. There has to be more written off, there must be.
There must be some honesty with the Canadian public. The government must admit that we are never going to get that money anyway, that it was the banks that have been benefiting year after year after year on that issue, and that we are paying for it through bank interest rates, et cetera.
The Liberal member has demonstrated that he has the same lack of global vision that permeates the Conservative caucus. He demonstrates that it permeates the Liberal caucus as well. The only choice in the next election is the New Democratic Party.
[Translation)

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make some comments further to the speech by the hon. member for Saanich-Gulf Islands. I heard the member say that we had to spend more on education, health and so on. Of course it is a priority to maintain those services. But we must also add that we have reached a certain level, which I think is very satisfactory and we need only maintain it. I think that we must first create some wealth. We should first create the wealth to be able one day to pay this frightful accumulated debt of $400 billion.
In 1984, when I was elected, we said that we absolutely must reduce the debt. Unfortunately, at that time, revenues were about $75 billion and expenditures $110 billion. Today, we see that revenues are about $135
Supply
billion and expenditures $165 billion, so we have not really succeeded in controlling government spending.
I think that we should create wealth. How do we create wealth? We had examples like free trade. Free trade was badly handled. We should have prepared for it, because if you open new markets, you must train the work force properly to deal with those changes. The dollar must also be kept as low as normally possible to encourage exports. Interest rates must also be reasonable so that our businesses can raise funds and thus create jobs. That was not done. Basically, free trade is a good thing, but it was so badly mishandled that jobs were lost. Our unemployment rate is now 11.5 per cent. I must say to the hon. member that we cannot think only of spending; we must also think of creating wealth, jobs and prosperous businesses so that we can then redistribute that wealth. So my question for her is how does she see the way of creating-

Mr. Speaker, I see that the right wing thinking that has been demonstrated by the Conservative government and the Liberal opposition also permeates the Bloc Quebecois caucus. There is only that one choice. We do not have to create wealth, we have to redistribute wealth.
Rio de Janiero is a city of vast wealth, 12 million people in one city. There is a huge contrast between the vast wealth and the extreme poverty. We do not need more wealth, we just need more equitable distribution of it. That is the kind of vision that we need, not just in Canada but globally. We do not need more greed, we need solutions for all people on the planet. We do not need to act out of narrow self-interest.
We should act out of self-interest because it is our survival we are talking about, and that is the only thing that should motivate us.

Mr. Speaker, like others in the House today I am very interested in participating in this debate. I think that even my colleagues on the front benches will agree that this is not utopia but, as others have mentioned in the House today, our number one ranking in the world obviously means we are pretty important. There is no doubt in my mind that

June 16, 1992
Supply
if we continue down the road we are on, with the leadership we have, we eventually will get a lot closer to utopia than we are today.
I had the opportunity to read some mail and some news clippings earlier this morning. There was a significant news clipping that came out of Washington, D.C., in which the media in Washington was questioning why the American government could not follow the same lines and same type of leadership as the Canadian government with regard to deficit reduction. Quite a number of my colleagues in the House have spoken to deficit reduction.
In my comments this afternoon I would like to deal with some of the successes of this government, particularly one specific program. It seems that members opposite are constantly nit-picking at various issues, although some of them may be important. At the end of the day they very seldom have compliments about the successful programs and efforts of this government.
The one program I would like to mention today is the Western Economic Diversification Program. The program was specifically put in place to promote the diversification of the economy in western Canada. In northern Ontario there is the FEDNOR Program and Atlantic Canada has the ACOA Program. I think that one of the most successful programs the government has introduced since 1984 has been the Western Economic Diversification Program.
The program is not meant to pit one person against another in terms of business competition. The program was put in place to diversify the economy, not to have a program financing people to compete against one another in a local community, in western Canada or in all of Canada. The specifics of the program lead the applicants to look at providing new products, new markets, new technologies, industry-wide competitiveness and most importantly, import replacements.
There is no funding for internal competition with existing companies or industries.
The program, as a result of being located in western Canada, has a western Canadian theme and western Canadian attitude. The head office is in Edmonton, there is a satellite office in each of the western provinces, and a liaison office here in Ottawa. It shows that the government understands that to put regional programs into place the management of those programs should be in the area that they are working within.
The program guidelines are very simple. We are looking for new products and new markets, but except for the very complicated projects that western diversification examines, most of those decisions are made in provincial or regional offices so that the applications by various companies and industries are reacted upon and processed extremely quickly.
Probably the most significant part of the western diversification concept is the fact that by far the biggest majority of all the monies that go out are in the form of repayable loans. The Government of Canada is not going out and giving money away and granting money to industry.
The Government of Canada has decided that if this is a business venture that will fly but needs a little kick-start then western diversification helps kick-start that particular project. At the end of the day the Government of Canada is asking those industries to repay their loans.
Like most things in life, the ones that you earn yourself are probably more respected than the ones that are given to you. That is probably one significant issue that arises from western diversification. You go in there and you work hard. At the end of the day you pay your debts, you feel well, and there is no indebtedness to somebody else.
There are a number of different aspects to western diversification. One of the ones that has been utilized most recently is the Quality Assurance Assistance Program. That particular program entails support from western diversification to take existing industries and help them upgrade to international standards.
Any Canadian company, whether it be in western Canada or elsewhere in Canada, that wants to compete in the international market knows that the standards that are required today are extremely high. If it does not have those standards it cannot compete in the international marketplace.
Those of us from western Canada truly believe we can compete any place in the world. With a little bit of repayable help from WD our industries in western Canada have had the ability to upgrade their facilities, get help from experts to make sure their quality reaches the required standard, and ensure they meet the international guidelines.
June 16, 1992

A lot of industry in western Canada will eventually be coming to western diversification. If not for funding they will be coming for guidance on how to meet these international standards.
Western diversification also gets involved with international marketing. A lot of smaller companies in western Canada have products that meet the international standards but they do not have the financial ability to enter the international marketplace to expand their markets.
Western diversification has taken a leadership role in promoting our products outside of Canada and in bringing people into western Canada to look at our ability to manufacture various goods.
The member for Saanich-Gulf Islands was making comments about this government's involvement in the environment. Western diversification, understanding the importance of the environment, took a leadership role a number of years ago in becoming involved with the South Moresby National Park. It has put well in excess of $100 million into the South Moresby park project to sustain a very special environmental area in Canada.
Western diversification also gets involved with projects dealing with various environmental standards and research. A good example is research into the low sulphur coal in western Canada that could be used in Ontario. We have a lot of quality coal which has a little bit too much sulphur and if the problem of getting rid of the sulphur emissions can be resolved, and they are working very hard at it today, I know that those colleagues of ours from eastern Canada will accept some western coal that is of good quality.
Western diversification has also entered into what has been called the partnership programs. I guess most of the House would remember this as an extension to what I remember as being the ERDAs.
We have had the ability to work with the provincial governments in western Canada dealing with forestiy, mines, tourism, communications technologies. We had another program with the federal government, with the funds funnelled through western diversification, to each of the four western provinces. Each province had the ability to spend the money as it saw fit which would encourage economic diversification in its province.
Supply
The one that I can speak best about is one in the province of Manitoba. Through western diversification and the province of Manitoba, a number of small community infrastructure improvements are taking place as we speak so that the infrastructure is in place either to expand existing industries in a number of small communities or to attract a number of industries to these communities because they have the sewer and water facilities ready to go.
Western diversification has been a leader in co-ordinating various government procurement initiatives. The last speaker was talking about helicopters as an example of purchases that are veiy significant.
Whether it is fortunate or unfortunate, very few Canadians know about the activities of western diversification. The Government of Canada has made some very significant purchases that are situated completely in western Canada. As an example I would mention what is known as the CAATS program, which is the Canadian Automated Air Traffic System.
It was Hughes Aircraft which picked up the contract. This contract is worth over $380 million and from what I understand, by the time the Hughes company has finished investing in western Canada, along with the $380 million contract, the Hughes Corporation is looking at spending another $500 million in various types of industrial development. Once again the area that I know best is Winnipeg, and it has already set up a specific company to deal with the acoustics industry.
Another one is the Thctical Command Control and Communications System. The successful bidder has a contract worth $1.2 billion, the majority of which will be spent in western Canada.
When we look at some of the other expenditures the government is making throughout Canada, western Canadians will see from these two specific examples what the government is doing to diversify the economy into western Canada.
Western diversification is also very much involved in the sole source contract to Bristol Aerospace for the CF-116 update which is a complete update of the 18-year old CF-5 aircraft to give it an extended life. At the same time, the experience that Bristol Aerospace Limited has picked up has allowed it to expand into international markets. The company has attracted a

June 16, 1992
Supply
significant amount of business from other countries in the world that need their CF-5 aircraft upgraded.
Not much more than six or eight months ago Western Star Trucks of Kelowna, B.C. was awarded a $200 million contract to provide DND with 2,750 trucks and shelters over the next few years. This contract provided over 350 jobs for the Kelowna area and maintained an existing industry probably longer than was initially expected.
I would like to talk about a couple of specific projects close to home in Manitoba. One is the Centre for Biodiagnostics which was announced a while ago. From what I understand, on Monday a representative of the government will be out to officially open the biodiagnostic centre. This initiative is a three-way co-operative effort, with western diversification putting some funding into the project, the National Research Council putting in a third of the funding and private industry putting in a third of the funding.
Within a very short period of time I think that we will find that the centre in Winnipeg will probably be the international centre for biodiagnostics in the world.
Another favourite project of mine which I believe eventually will be somewhere in western Canada and which will provide over 400 jobs, but is in the research and development stage right now, is that of Meadow Materials. Meadow Materials has taken it upon themselves to do research into how to take silica sand, which is a very significant commodity within the riding of Selkirk-Red River, being probably the supplier of the best silica in the world. Western diversification is working with Meadow Materials and the Manitoba government in doing the technology improvement so that silica sand along with apparently other materials will be able to make silicon metal. It seems very simplistic in a statement but the estimated job opportunities when the project comes to completion is well over 400. When you come from a community such as Selkirk-Red River 400 jobs in that area is very significant.
I commend the western diversification people for their efforts in making that actually happen.
To sum up, I have made comments about how maybe things are not exactly perfect here and although I do not think they are that significant, some of the decisions that
we have made in government have not been perfect or idealistic. What I would like to put to the members opposite is that I think there are times when the government does do a good job and does come up with progressive thinking and provides jobs and opportunities in a very progressive way.
I guess what I am asking is that the members opposite sometimes give credit where credit is due.

Mr. Speaker, we might have forgotten in the last 18 minutes or so that my friend and hon. colleague opposite said that we had been excessive in our criticisms of the government and in fact we were well on our way to Utopia. That is what he said "well on our way to Utopia which could be accomplished if this government was re-elected". He said, Mr. Speaker, I know you heard it because my hon. colleague on this side heard him say that there was an awful lot of nit-picking that obscured the pursuit of the ideal perfection of the universe in Canada under the hegemony of the Conservative government. I suppose the last time we came so close to Utopia was during the recession when we lost 29.7 per cent of our manufacturing jobs. I guess it is true we have not yet achieved Utopia since so far this government has cost only 25.5 per cent of our manufacturing jobs through its free trade agreement. Just to put that into context, Utopia so far has cost us 510,000 manufacturing jobs.
In the 1981-82 Liberal Utopia, 270,000 jobs were lost. In fact only about 22 per cent of those were permanent job losses. Under present circumstances, the loss of
510,000	jobs in manufacturing in this Utopia constitutes 65 per cent of permanent job losses.
Just to give you an idea of the practical impact of that, six plants have closed in Windsor in the last two weeks, and nearly 40 plants have been lost in Windsor alone in this Utopia since 1989.
Others have cited the practical effect on ordinary human beings. We know there is a crisis among young people in this new Utopia and I do not want to be nit-picking. I do not want to nit-pick but I guess it is nit-picking to tell the hon. member we have an unemployment rate among youth of 17.7 per cent right now. That is almost 18 per cent unemployment among youth. There is a drop-out rate of 30 per cent among youth and also a 40 per cent illiteracy and innumeracy rate.
June 16, 1992

Supply
The impact of these circumstances on our youth in this Utopia is an increase in property crimes among youth of 57 per cent since this government has been building this Utopia.

Mr. Speaker, I would not say that is particularly nit-picking but I am glad the member brought up the problems he has in his own community of Windsor. The honourable member and I sat on a committee that did significant research into the auto parts industry. We found government policies which preceded us such as the National Energy Program, the low value of the dollar and the auto pact created an industry in southern Ontario that was not competitive.
The problem we have today is former policies, which people probably thought were all right at the time, but obviously did not work. As a result, we are going through a significant adjustment. I feel sorry for anybody who does not have a job, but these people do not have jobs because they are not high-tech. The reason they are not high-tech is the fact they work in a low-tech factory which is no longer competitive. If the leadership at that time had forced industry to modernize, educate its workers and be competitive, maybe we would not have the problems we have today.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate. Today we are discussing whether or not we should agree to give this government $48,902,383,552.00.
That is the decision we have to make. That is in the bill before us. I want to say to the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona I did not prepare this bill, but that is what is asked of us.
Now should we give $48,902,383,552 to those clowns across the way? That is the decision for us to make.
Let us evaluate what it did with the money we gave it last time. As you know, this House has voted money for this government on a number of occasions. Let us review some of its expenditures.
Only a few short days ago I asked the government how many departments and agencies presently had outstanding computer contracts, not the ones that are finished,
not the ones that are over, not the ones they gave to their friends and have been completed, just the ones still in progress. Do you know what the answer was? The answer was $1,123,498,026.58. Those are just the outstanding contracts. My colleague asks very appropriately, does it not have enough? Seemingly not. This is what it is up to.
In my continuing quest to find out whether or not we should give this amount of $48 billion to the government across the way, more particularly to the Prime Minister, I asked other questions. It has come to my attention the Government of Canada does not trust Canada Post. I do not know why anyone would not trust Canada Post. I cannot think of any reason. But the Government of Canada used Interpost, which is a Dutch postal system partially owned by the Dutch government, partially owned by KLM Airlines and partially owned by a great Canadian company, Northwest Airlines of the United States.
It gave $733,000 worth of contracts to deliver the mail to this particular Dutch company over a recent period. Let me draw a parallel for my colleagues here in the House. That is a little bit like me owning a taxi company and using someone else's taxi-cab to go around town.
Save gas?

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
I suppose it would save gas in my own cab, but it would not make much business sense. Then again, the government across the way does not make much business sense. The Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources used $301,000 worth of this particular service. Do you know the reason he gave me? Interpost offered low rates and "reliable service". The government used the Dutch post office to deliver its mail because it gave reliable service. What does that say about the Canadian postal system it owns and runs on behalf of the people of Canada? It tells me this government does not trust its own corporation.
That is not the only area where this government has wasted money. This government has been wasting money since it has been in power. It has been buying limousines, travelling around, doing all kinds of things and just wasting taxpayers' money like you would not believe. We have a first-class Minister of External Affairs who proved her class to all of us recently when she broke the

June 16, 1992
Supply
edict of the Minister of Finance travelling here and there.
First class travel.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Last year it came to my attention this government had built a dog house in Rigaud. This particular dog house in Rigaud is at the Customs and Excise training college. Canadians were howling mad when they heard the price of this particular dog house. It cost $325,000 to house 10 of our salivating friends in Rigaud.
Do you know why it built the kennel in question? Because the old one was on the tennis court and the good people there, the head honchos at the place, wanted their tennis court back. What did they do? They ordered a new one built so they could practise their backhand courtesy of the taxpayers of Canada. This cost $325,000.
The amazing thing about it is the original cost was $226,800, but there was almost $100,000 in cost overruns on a dog house, if you can believe it.
That is like going to the dogs.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
No wonder we are going to the dogs in this country.
I have been asking this government a number of questions. Again, I am trying to hold it accountable in an effort to make up my mind as to whether or not we should give it another $48 billion. I asked how many computer contracts were given to install the various computer systems for the GST. That sounds like a reasonable proposition. After all, the GST was much dreaded by most Canadians and much heralded by the Tories across the way. They even appointed eight extra GST-loving Senators to get it through the other place. Anyway it cost $9,343,771 in computer contracts over six months between January 1, 1991 and June 30, 1991.
And it did not have to pay the GST either.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
You are right. My colleague is quite correct. They did not even pay GST on those particular computer contracts.
I also want to talk a little bit about advertising. This government is quite good at advertising. I remember
when the present Minister of Communications was a mortal opposition member and used to criticize the government. He said about government advertising at the time, which was minuscule compared to today, and I quote from May 3, 1982, Hansard'.
"If the present situation is allowed to continue unchecked, we will find that the essential equilibrium between government and opposition, which has existed over centuries of parliamentary democracy, will be destroyed".
Those were the words of that member. Do you know who the top spenders in advertising in Canada were in 1989? The Government of Canada was first with $76 million in advertising; Proctor and Gamble was second with $61 million; GM spent $56 million and the others, of course, are much smaller. Those are the kinds of expenditures we have seen.
I will give a few other instances here. I could go on for quite some time, but unfortunately time will not permit. I want to bring to your attention the leasing of real property by this government. In its budget two years ago this government cancelled the construction of new headquarters for Transport Canada. It renewed the lease on Place de Ville here in Ottawa and spent $170 million to rent the building, which the government is renovating. The employees will be working in a construction site for no less than eight years while the building is being renovated for the ultimate benefit of the Campeau Corporation, not the tenant or the employees in the building.
Questions were asked at that time about how this happened, who lobbied for this contract and so on.

Mr. Speaker, having consulted my colleagues, I must tell you that we have concluded that we will refuse to give the government the $48 billion it is asking us for today.
Let us give the message to Canadians that this government does not need an extra $48 billion. It deserves a kick in the pants, which is what we will do at the next election.
June 16, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I would just like to ask a very quick question of the hon. member.
He talks about whether or not the $48 billion should come to the government. Back in 1980 or 1981 the Liberal government was coming forward and asking for money. It was not really money because the government was asking that it be put on the credit card. In essence, I think every Canadian can understand that back in 1983 for every dollar of tax revenue the Liberal government was providing about $1.23 in services. Imagine that, Mr. Speaker.
Where was that extra 22 or 23 cents going? It was going on that Visa credit card and then the MasterCard because that was over-exposed. All the balances on those credit cards kept going up.
Now we are hearing the member moan and groan as the government is trying to get its fiscal ship back in order. Today, for every dollar in tax revenue there is about 95 or 96 cents going toward services. We have made that adjustment.
Is the member suggesting that the government should go back and is he concerned that it is only $48 billion? If we were following the policies of the Liberal Party ten years ago we should be requesting $96 billion and just putting those balances on the credit card.
I would like him to explain if indeed that is the case, why we are not asking for $96 billion instead of only $48 billion.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
It is always nice to get a question about credit cards from the government that gave us the American Express bank.
I find it interesting that a government member would be asking a question on credit cards. The government gave us the Amex bank, signed it by an Order in Council the day of the last election, probably in the fear that it was going to be turfed out on its ear and that if its friends at Amex could not be rewarded, the way to-
It didn't happen.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
The member says that it did not happen. No, it did not, but we will get to them next time.
The member asks us about fiscal responsibility. That is interesting given that one half of the accumulated debt
Supply
in the history of Canada is there courtesy of the present Prime Minister and his administration.
In other words, the $400 billion debt we have today was only $200 billion in 1984, immediately after a very severe world-wide recession. After years of prosperity this government made it worse.
The member asks me how much I think the $48 billion should be. He has missed the point. The point is that Canadians have no faith in this government. Canadians do not trust this government to administer their money nor the affairs of the nation.
That is why my colleagues and I do not want to give any authority to this government to be running the affairs of the nation. It is not a bill that the government should be asking for; it is an election. That is what we need.

If in 1984 there had been a $200 billion surplus and now through compound interest it had grown to $400 billion, would you be upset by that? That is exactly what has happened to the national debt. It was $200 billion in 1984 and the compound interest on that debt has grown and doubled right now.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, this government is telling us that after some six years of prosperity, the last year and a half or so in a recession largely caused by the policies of this government, the best it could do was to double the debt in Canada. And government members are asking me to explain that kind of mismanagement? I am sorry, neither I nor the Canadian public can explain that, but they do understand it and they will take care of it very shortly.

Mr. Speaker, on the other side of this House sits the Tory government which has always been on the best of terms with the business sector. But what has this government done? During the last three years, our country has been undergoing a de-industrialization process. During the last three years, we lost 16 per cent of our manufacturing jobs while the United States lost only 7 per cent of jobs in that area. Therefore, this cannot be due entirely to restructuring, globalization and the recession.

Supply
Incompetence.
It must be due in part to the lack of economic ability of this government.
That's it.

In the automotive industry, our major manufacturing industry, the one which exports the most, during the last three years, we lost 21 per cent of our jobs, while in the U.S. the job loss figure was only 9 per cent. In other words, in the automobile industry, Canada is losing jobs 2.3 times faster than the U.S.
The last figures show an increase in unemployment. We are still in a recession and what is even worse is that those permanent jobs disappearing in Canada are moving to the U.S. and to other countries. As a country, it will be very difficult for us to adjust to that situation, but we have to start somewhere; all is not lost. There is still something we can do. First, we must create adjustment programs, those programs which were promised by this Toiy government before the with the United States but which were never put in place.
Our objective must be to make Canadians the best educated, the best trained and the best equipped workers of the western hemisphere. If we reach that goal, we will see economical results in 10 or 20 years from now I hope.
We must remember that only the private sector can generate jobs and wealth.
That wealth is essential, not only for job creation, but also to reduce the deficit. We cannot increase taxes any more; it is impossible. Canadians have reached the point of ignition on the subject of taxes.
Let us be honest. Nobody in this House can tell us how to cut spending so that we can solve the deficit problem. What we must do is give the private sector the means to generate wealth, pay taxes, create jobs and transform the unemployed into taxpayers. That is what has to be done.
lb do that, the government must change many of its policies, such as its monetary policy which has translated, over a period of 20 years, into an increase of more than 25 per cent of the value of our currency. This is an incredible burden for our exporters. This is a government that was not supposed to increase taxes, but it has done so 34 times since it came to power. It has also given us much higher interest rates, a very high currency rate,
as well as taxes that are too high, while at the same time presenting us with the free trade agreement. Our exporters must face an incredible challenge trying to keep up with the American competition. This was not fair and we have seen the results of those measures.
There is another thing that must be done. It has to do with the relations between workers and employers and businesses. In Canada, we have the worst record among the 23 developed countries when it comes to the number of days lost because of strikes and lockouts. We have the worst record and the example came from this government when everybody saw what it did to its own employees.
I now want to say a word about training which was cut by this government. It is a cut of the contribution made from the general revenue for the training of Canadians. This contribution should in fact be increased so that we can become better equipped and better educated.
Let us now talk about science and technology, as well as research and development. Again, those sectors suffered cuts from the government. How can we face the competition at the international level, as well as globalization, when our level of research and development is but half of that of other countries?
Finally, there is the issue of co-operation between the three sectors, that is the workers, the contractors and the various levels of government. In Canada, we do not yet have the will nor the means to create this kind of partnership amongst the three groups, each of which is essential to job creation as well as prosperity in Canada.
In conclusion, I want to say that we must not be partisan when it comes to Canadian unity. We must remain united so that we can regain the potential that we used to have and that most Canadians now feel we have lost. If we do not work together, it will not be possible to envision a prosperous future and a country that enhances its capacity as well as the potential of its citizens, and in particular its young people who cannot find jobs right now.
Mr. Speaker, you will have noticed that in your own riding young people have nothing to do. When they ask: "What shall I do to find a job? I have a good education and I can work", what is your answer? What is the answer of my other colleagues? Must we tell them: "Wait"?
